story:
About the Project

The Plot

Rose, 16, was up all night dealing with two equally annoying pests-- a horny boyfriend and a squeaking mouse that has somehow managed to climb into her bedroom ceiling. With her mother across the country attending a distant relative's funeral, Rose is home alone, and her boyfriend George is eager to capitalize on the opportunity. However, when Rose finds out that the mouse giving her a migraine scampered under her bed and ate a bag of her marijuana edibles, she and George must decide its fate.

So... a mouse? (Director's Statement)

In the first few months of quarantine, back when it felt more like a vacation from real life responsibilities (i.e. working late night shifts as a hostess) than a sentence to purgatory, I started reading a book I had bought at the Getty Museum in California a year prior. It was a modern translation of a medieval “bestiary”, a collection of encyclopedia-style entries about various real and fictional animals. The text itself was funny, bizarre, and at some points, very dark, and by the end of reading The Bestiary I felt compelled to write something about animals that dealt with death. You see, in these medieval entries, every animal had a Christ-like significance. They would die and resurrect, kill their pups—all of the sort of darkness you could expect from a text from such a bleak period in history. I started to write a radio play about rats. I figured if I finished the script by June 2020, I’d be able to record all the parts before the academic year began.

Quarantine, however, ended up far more eventful than I could have ever anticipated, and the idea was scrapped during the June protests that swept the nation. I was very disappointed to begin the semester without a quarantine project under my belt. And I was even more disappointed to have never written something quirky about rats. 

Ultimately, this became the generative idea for Mercy for the Meek—I traded gritty sewer rats for docile mice, and decided to craft a story that dealt with very serious issues around a drama that I could more easily wrap my 20-year-old head around: teenage hormones.  The conceit of Mercy for the Meek is that it’s a comedy surrounded by bleakness and awfulness (which I think is timely). Much like the medieval texts I read, the subject matter is at times dark, but (also like the medieval texts I read) the presentation of all this absurdity and terror is funny. 

Right before I began to write the second draft of this script, I was forced to put down my family dog of fifteen years. It was an intense experience to watch the eyes of an animal as it dies—especially one that I loved dearly. But it is an experience that, as a human on the precipice of true adulthood, I am happy to have had. Because I think it taught me, on a base level, the preciousness and fragility of life, and how much power I have as a person with opposable thumbs. In Mercy for the Meek, Rose comes to a similar realization. I hope that when you watch this short film this human tenderness—above all the bleakness and dark comedy— moves you as much as it moves me.

Key Crew

I am a 21 year old writer director based in Philadelphia, currently pursuing a BFA in screenwriting at Temple University. Throughout the last three years, I have been privileged to work on many sets and direct multiple short projects on shoe-string budgets, the most notable being Love is Wet (2020), a sex-comedy shot in a day that follows a young couple navigating their modern relationship. Love is Wet  won the Audience Award at the Diamond Screen Women's Film Fest and is a finalist at Flickfair. For my full creative resume, please click here.

I am deeply committed to telling stories from a female perspective that are off the beaten path, funny, and profound. 

Jacob Rosinski is a cinematographer based in the greater Baltimore area. Jacob has shot a number of projects, including Away Out on the Mountains (2020), a meditative piece about a man and his dog; Complexion (2019), a short directed by Temple BFA directing student Jaran Huggins about colorism; and Dinger (2019), a stomach-turning comedy about pick up artists.

Key Cast

Jasmine Chesbro and Andrew Schmid are incredibly talented actors that have been integral to the production of the Mercy for the Meek script. Both have read for their parts during zoom recorded table reads that can be accessed by request. 

Risks & Challenges

All films, regardless of the budget, size of crew, or subject matter, are labors of love. But the COVID-19 pandemic has brought unique conditions to film productions that are difficult to account for. Although the majority (if not all) of the cast and crew will likely be vaccinated by our August shoot dates, State mandates and decisions are completely out of our control. Your donations will give us flexibility and allow us to keep our cast and crew as safe as possible on set.

This film will also be utilizing animal talent, which is incredibly exciting! We have a trained mouse and animal handler who will be flying in from LA to join our team! Although this is a large expense, we believe that it is vital to maintain a professional set with the humane treatment of animals.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, here are some other ways you can help me make Mercy for the Meek:

  • Share this campaign on social media! 
  • Visit our website! 
  • Support the film at festivals!

story:
“The 48 Film Festival is a time-based film challenge exclusive to Canadian film artists."

 

What's a 48 Film Challenge? 

In short, it's a weekend challenge where collaborators write, shoot, score, edit and deliver an original short film in two days. 

About Us

The 48 Film Festival is a not-for-profit, Canadian arts support organization that offers a kick-ass national film festival open to all provinces and territories.

 

Our Vision

We want artists to become hometown heroes; a fanfare similar to sports fans who cheer on their favourite local players and teams.

We aim to energize the arts nationwide and elevate artist career paths in Canada.

  • All teams will screen locally in each participating region.
  • Top two films screen at TIFF Lightbox in Toronto (Spring 2022).
  • Partners with Canadian arts centres in 8 provinces and 2 territories.  

Want to contribute? So far, everything has come out of pocket and built by a small volunteer staff and interns.  Goodwill and personal resources go ever so far, so now we are reaching out to the general public. We could use your help.

 

How will the funds be used? We believe in equitable compensation for artists and  those who administer support for artists and their work. See the graphic below to learn about the various ways in which we intend to use the funds.

 

 

 

 

 

 

New Filmic Merch Store
The world’s first filmic merch store for film artists.
Indiegogo backers will get our exclusive deals first.

 

 

 

How Can I Help?

With regard to Indiegogo, every dollar counts and all funds raised for this campaign will help cover costs for artists and those who directly administer support. 

 

 

Other ways I can help? 

  1. Sponsor an event/activity.
  2. Sponsor a filmmaker/team.
  3. Sponsor a non-monetary gift/prize.
  4. Sponsor your own custom made donation.
  5. Follow us online and help spread the word.

    

 

 

 

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

Regardless of experience and resources, unforeseen obstacles do emerge and can potentially hamper momentum and activities.

 

RISK #1 – Season Cancelled 2020/21

February 27, 2020, the Winnipeg Film Group presented: "The 48” a 6-year retrospective at the TIFF Bell Lightbox, in Toronto – prelude to the Canada-wide 48 Film Challenge.

This pre-COVID lockdown screening, forced us to ditch all plans for the Canada-wide Challenge for the 2020/21 season. We have made the adjustment.

 
 
 

RISK #2 – The COVID Barrier 

  1. We cannot safely do in-person events or screenings.
  2. It will be a challenge for production shoots summer 2021.
  3. The audience will miss out on the in-person theatre experience.
  4. Participants will miss on-set bonding and in-person engagements. 

Solutions: We've enlisted On Screen Manitoba to produce a video (COVID safe on-off-set protocols) with downloadable PDF for all participants. 

 

 

RISK #3 – Canadian Arts Funding 

We have yet to receive operational funding from public or private funding body at this time. 

Solutions: We have been taping various funding streams like crowdfunding, virtual silent auctions and our new Filmic Merch Store as well as other means like registrations, member dues and screening fees.

story:
In these uncertain times, the world population experiences the historical challenge of the global pandemic. The outbreak of the virus has a profound impact on older adults' mental health and well-being. For many frail older adults living alone, social activities such as attending church and family visits are an important way for them to feel socially connected. However, due to the restrictions, an increasing number of older adults are facing social isolation and are already at risk of stress, anxiety, and depression.

Secondly, according to a study by the Canadian Federation of Humane Societies, Canada has a cat overpopulation and homelessness problem.

Through this film, we aim to bring awareness towards both topics.

We are plan to shoot this in 2021 winter.

With a project as ambitious as this, we are asking for help to make this film as realistic as possible. In order to achieve our goal, we require a trained cat on set as our furry friend will be the main star of the film. We have an amazing crew of very talented filmmakers and most of the funding will go towards the cat, locations, equipment rental for camera, light, lenses, etc. 

Although we aim to put as much money as we can towards the high-quality production, we need to make sure the cast and crew are well fed. Other things to consider include transportation, production design, post-production, film festival fees, etc...

Any additional funds will be donated to cat shelters

Director - Akbar Khan 

Producer - Elaine Yan 

Screenwriter - Joseph Findlay 

Director of Photography - Korey Mansumori 

Korey Masumori was born and raised on the tropical island called Okinawa. Unlike any other parts of Japan, Okinawa has clear influences from China and the U.S.. He grew up playing ice hockey and watching Disney Channel. He worked as Cinematopher on the short Hiraeth.

 Production Designer - Madison Stenner 

Madison Stenner is a California native, published poet, and lover of storytelling in all forms, but has found a love in production design as a way to blend art and story. Notably, she worked as a set designer on the feature The Making of Me.


"The focus of this inspirational, heart-warming drama is based on the “companionship” theme, through the passing of a simple furry animal as a gift to an elderly in need of a smile or an extra comfort; as he mourns for his wife. My visual inspiration comes mainly from the dramatic, deep emotive Pixar films such as Up, Coco, and Onward. Pixar’s stories tend to resonate due to their willingness to explore complex emotions, particularly the impact of death. Death might seem like a strange and unnecessary dark subject for any demographic. But crucially, they always show a way forward, careful to balance tragedy with hope and optimism. Similarly, this film depicts the death of a beloved family member, but the elderly protagonist learns to move forward, to appreciate the living, while honoring the dead."

Pixar is well known for making great animation films but what if, Pixar decides to make a live-action short film? What will that look like?

We are trying to create a Pixar-esque short film.

We are also filming during the COVID-19 pandemic, and that is an additional risk for us. We will have qualified COVID-19 staff present on set to insure everyone's safety. Anyone working on set is required to wear a mask at all times. Face shield is required for close-proximity tasks. Hand sanitizer is required at enter the set, every time.

In the short term, we would love to submit this to as many festivals as possible. The ultimate goal would be to pitch this short and become a feature.

Please share this to spread awareness of the project.

While we are doing everything within our power to spread word of this project amongst our networks, you can help boost its reach by sharing it with your family, friends, and individuals who you know that could relate to this story. It is our goal to spread the message of this film to as large an audience as possible and we can make that goal a reality with your help!

Just send this cast and crew some love and good vibes. We could all use a little positivity :)

Please contact us if you have any questions: companionshortfilm@gmail.com

story:
LEGAL NOTE: This documentary was not sponsored or endorsed by The Tetris Company.

The Basics

  • Six-episode documentary series about Classic Tetris champions competing at the Classic Tetris World Championship.
  • Includes extensive interviews + HD remastered gameplay footage with brand-new commentary by Chris Tang and James Chen.
  • Brought to you by the team behind CTWC, Ecstasy of Order: The Tetris Masters, and other Classic Tetris stuff!

 

Here's My Story

In the months before the 2014 Classic Tetris World Championship, I (Chris Higgins) began filming a sequel to the documentary Ecstasy of Order: The Tetris Masters. (I worked on EOO as a writer.) 2014 was the fifth annual CTWC, and I interviewed key players before, during, and after the competition to learn what Classic Tetris meant to them. I made a film about how the Classic Tetris scene had changed in the years since EOO.

Filming continued through late 2015 in Oregon, California, and Europe. There was even some footage captured in 2016 as I continued to fill in gaps. I ended up with a massive project that couldn't really fit in the 90-minute format I originally planned on. I had hours of championship gameplay footage alone—not to mention dozens of interviews with players and experts. I continued to work on it around the edges for several years, but focused on other projects as I tried to figure out how to complete this movie.

Terry Purcell plays his then-beloved controller "Turd" during the championship.

When the pandemic struck in March 2020, I found myself suddenly unemployed. I was working as a portrait photographer, which wasn't a high-demand job during lockdown.

So I spoke with my friend Gilbert Tang, and he proposed a clear solution: This should be a documentary series. If we released it online to backers, there would be no need to cut it down to 90 minutes for a theatrical release. We would just make the episodes and release them as they were done.

I also believe it's vital to add new game commentary from both Chris Tang and James Chen. (Tang was the lone commentator back in 2014.) They are onboard to record brand-new commentary for this series!

 

The Team

Chris Higgins (Director) - I'm a writer, podcaster, and filmmaker. I make my living telling true stories. You might know me from my reporting on This American Life (that was later adapted into a movie), my writing for Mental Floss magazine, my work writing and hosting the Election Ride Home podcast, my books, or whatever. I directed this movie, plus served in the camera and sound departments.

Carl King (Editor & Original Score) - In the progressive rock world, Carl King has released albums under the names Sir Millard Mulch and Dr. Zoltan. He’s made music with Dweezil Zappa, Virgil Donati, Mike Keneally, Marco Minnemann, Travis Orbin, and others. His triple-CD concept album, HOW TO SELL THE WHOLE F#@!ING UNIVERSE TO EVERYBODY, ONCE AND FOR ALL! was co-released on Mimicry Records owned by Trey Spruance of Mr. Bungle. His favorite composers are Prokofiev, Stravinsky, and John Williams. 

Adam Cornelius, Vince Clemente, Trey Harrison (Producers) - The core team behind both the Classic Tetris World Championship (CTWC) itself and the previous Classic Tetris documentary, Ecstasy of Order, all worked on this project. Vince helped set up access to the event. Adam helped edit and organize footage. Trey digitized gameplay footage using his "Treyvision" system, turning fuzzy TV recordings into HD gameplay (more on that below).

Josh Boykin (Narrator) - Josh Boykin is a game critic, streamer, narrator, and speaker who focuses on storytelling and narrative in games. As the Founder of Intelligame, he builds community around discussing all kinds of games and the connections players can make with the real world. He also carries a very pure, very strong love for Tetris Effect. You can find him on Twitter and you can find Intelligame on Twitter, Twitch, and Patreon.

Chris Tang, James Chen (Commentators) - Chris Tang and James Chen have been part of the CTWC commentary team in recent years. Chen is a historian, advocate, and commentator for the Fighting Game Community. Tang is a game designer, eSports commentator, and recently appleared in the Netflix documentary High Score. He also coined the phrase "Boom! Tetris!"

Lucy Bellwood (Audio Description Narrator) - Lucy Bellwood is a professional Adventure Cartoonist, author, and educator based in Portland, Oregon. Her work brings enthusiastic tales of exploration to thousands of readers online, in print, and in person.

 

About the Rewards

What if you don't ship to my country? I have set up shipping to 22 countries based on our understanding of the demographics of the CTWC player base and viewership—but I'm sure I have missed some! If your country isn't listed, please leave a comment and I will add it (unless there is some legal or other reason I simply cannot get there from here). You can also email Chris directly if you have questions or concerns.

A classic CTWC shirt appears!

REWARD: The Series — You'll be able to access a stream of the series, episode by episode, as it is released. How it works: You get a special code via email that lets you make a (free) account on the streaming service and grab new episodes (or old ones you may have missed). When new episodes come out, you get an email and can log in to watch them. I anticipate six episodes, with the first one coming out by April 2021.

DIGITAL ADD-ON: Director's Commentary Streams — Taking a page from CGP Grey, I'll do live streams after each episode comes out. Tuning in to the live (or recorded) stream will require a secret link that you can only get if you've backed the appropriate level. Anyway, the stream involves me playing the episode, showing you the editing process, and bringing in special guests to talk about key moments and answering questions from y'all. If you're interested in behind-the-scenes stuff, or you just want to ask questions about the episode, this is for you. (Note: This add-on is available for every tier once you select your main reward. All the higher-priced reward tiers have it included, along with the series.)

DIGITAL ADD-ON: Original Soundtrack — Download the original soundtrack by Carl King! If you like Tetris music, this is for you. Carl wrote and performed all the music you hear in the video for this project, and that's just the beginning.

PHYSICAL ADD-ON: Stickers — This is a six-pack of vinyl stickers. They will come in various sizes, all with original designs related to the movie. I'm trying to keep them small enough to ship in a regular envelope, so expect most of these to be in the 3x3 inch size or thereabouts. I'll share designs as they're made.

PHYSICAL ADD-ON: Original Polaroid from the Editing Suite — An original Polaroid photo taken by Director Chris Higgins. Each is unique, and will document some aspect of editing the film. All are taken on original Polaroid SX-70 cameras, and will have flaws common to Polaroids—the film might be a little messed up, focus might be slightly off, and so on. Have a piece of original art for not much money! Below are a few examples taken over the past few months. These are images taken at Chris's desk. (Chris also runs the Instagram account for Jamie Livingston, who was one of the most noteworthy Polaroid photographers of the 20th century!)

Polaroid examples - a sealed ecosystem on Chris's desk (w/headphones), an early Instagram design, and a color-checker exposure test

REWARD: Movie Poster — An 18x24 inch movie poster, signed by the Director, suitable for framing or hanging up in your dorm room. Keep in mind that this is smaller than the giant movie posters you see at movie theaters, but it's still a nice medium-sized poster printed on high-quality paper in full color. I'm still working with our designer on the imagery, but, you know, it'll look like a movie poster for a Classic Tetris documentary.

REWARD: Blu-ray — A 1080p (HD) Blu-ray Disc with the full series, with the box signed by the Director. This includes subtitles (in whatever languages I have by the time the disc is made) as well as Audio Description in English. If you like collectibles and/or Blu-ray Discs, well, this is your thing. Note that this one arrives very late because it is the last thing I'll make for this series. Also note that this might have to turn into two discs, depending on the length of the episodes. I think I can cram it onto one disc, but I have budgeted for the possibility of it being a two-disc set. If that happens, y'all get that upgrade for free.

REWARD: Classic Gaming Photo Book — As I mentioned above, I've worked as a photographer for years. There were actually several years I covered the Portland Retro Gaming Expo (home to the Classic Tetris World Championship) doing photo essays for Mental Floss magazine. I have a ton of photos from over the years at retro gaming expos, CTWCs, and during the filming of this series. I'll pick out the best ones and make a nice, hardbound book of them (rough page count—probably 30-ish, double sided printing). Because these books are costly to make and ship, this will be a very limited edition reward. And yes, I will sign and number them.

REWARD: Chris Higgins Helps You — I do a lot of stuff, much of which you can find on my website. You get four hours of my time online for whatever (legal and morally acceptable) purpose we agree on. I'll give a talk for your company or group, I'll do consulting work, I'll fix your podcast's weird audio problem, or I'll just talk and hang out. Note that if you are in Portland, Oregon we may be able to do this in person, with safety protocols.

REWARD: Associate & Executive Producer Credits — You will actually join the team at these levels. Your name will be in the credits as an AP or EP, including the movie's IMDB page. (By the way, here's my IMDB page.) I will include you on internal team updates and show you rough cuts, ask for your input, and consider what you think as we shape each episode, and the series as a whole. If you've ever wanted to be a movie producer, well, here's your chance!

 

About Time, HD, and Treyvision

A big aspect of this documentary series is watching Classic Tetris gameplay in the tournament. If you've ever watched the tournament on the Classic Tetris YouTube channel, you know what that looks like: two Tetris games, side-by-side, in HD. That way of viewing the game includes live statistics (including a "drought counter" that tells you how long it has been since the last long bar) and a score differential. The system is sometimes called "Treyvision" after its inventor, Producer Trey Harrison.

A match rendered in HD Trevision for this series.

So why am I talking about this? Well, I filmed the tournament in 2014. Treyvision was invented after this movie was filmed. We did not have that technology in the old days. Back then, you just saw two TV screens projected on a big screen. No clean HD graphics, no statistics, no drought counter, no nothing. If the commentator wanted to know the score difference, they had to do math. What I had after wrapping production was very small, fuzzy recordings of each TV. (The interviews and stuff are all filmed in beautiful fancy HD, but the Nintendo outputs were not.)

At the very beginning of the pandemic lockdown, I reached out to Trey about his Treyvision system, hoping he could use it to render key games and matches in that HD format using the poor-quality recordings I had. He could, but it was extremely difficult. This was a heroic effort by Producer Trey, because he was working with source material that was deeply low-quality (classic "postage stamp video" complete with analog glitches and digital glitches in the source files). After Trey created the HD versions, there were still a variety of digital errors due to glitches in the source recordings. As Director, I went through each game frame by frame, spotting and painting out the glitches by hand. This is a big part of why preparing the footage has taken so long.

 

Accessibility and Closed Captions

I have a firm commitment to making all films accessible to people with disabilities. Every episode of this series will arrive with Closed Captions and Audio Description in English—at a minimum.

I'm looking for translators to help with Closed Captions in languages other than English. If you have experience with this process, please get in touch (especially if you know Tetris well—that should help with the translation process). Translation of captions is paid work. Note that I will not use or accept machine translation—I need humans to do this. I'd love to deliver each episode with a variety of Closed Caption tracks to reflect the worldwide community of Classic Tetris fans—but I need your help to make that happen.

 

How the Budget Works

A player reaches Level 29 during qualifying.

Anyway, without getting into the specific dollar amounts, the big cost categories for this project are (in this order):

Editing — the process of reviewing hundreds of hours of footage and cutting together sequences. This is the most expensive single line-item. It also implies the entire creative process of telling the many stories here, as we explain the rivalries and struggles of so many individual players in the tournament.

Narration — this series includes a lot of voices. We have Chris Tang and James Chen doing commentary—that is actually new commentary, as James wasn't part of the CTWC team back in 2014. We have to get these two commentators together safely to watch the games and record brand-new commentary. Beyond that, we also have Josh Boykin as the narrator of the film—he's the voice explaining things. And even beyond that, we have Lucy Bellwood as the Audio Description narrator—her voice is there to describe visual elements for people who are blind or visually impaired. (Audio Description is a second audio track that can be turned on or off.)

Score — Carl King is providing an original score for the entire series. Rather than using stock music, I'm doing the real thing. That takes time and money. You can hear his original score in the video above—that's all new music he made and performed for this series, and there will be a lot more where that came from!

Design & Graphics — every film needs a logo, titles, and a poster. In this one we will also need some motion graphics to visualize things like the brackets, so it's clear where the players are as they proceed through tournament play.

Closed Captions & Audio Description — as part of my commitment to accessibility, I'm providing Closed Captions and Audio Description (in English, at minimum). I also hope to add Closed Captions in other languages as well (check on the "Accessibility and Closed Captions" section above if you'd like to help).

NOTE: "Tetris" is a registered trademark of The Tetris Company, LLC (TTC). Use of the word "Tetris" does not imply any affiliation with or endorsement by TTC.

LEGAL NOTE: This documentary was not sponsored or endorsed by The Tetris Company.The Basics
Six-episode documentary series about Classic Tetris champions competing at the Classic Tetris World Championship.
Includes extensive interviews + HD remastered gameplay footage with brand-new commentary by Chris Tang and James Chen.
Brought to you by the team behind CTWC, Ecstasy of Order: The Tetris Masters, and other Classic Tetris stuff!
 Here's My StoryIn the months before the 2014 Classic Tetris World Championship, I (Chris Higgins) began filming a sequel to the documentary Ecstasy of Order: The Tetris Masters. (I worked on EOO as a writer.) 2014 was the fifth annual CTWC, and I interviewed key players before, during, and after the competition to learn what Classic Tetris meant to them. I made a film about how the Classic Tetris scene had changed in the years since EOO.Filming continued through late 2015 in Oregon, California, and Europe. There was even some footage captured in 2016 as I continued to fill in gaps. I ended up with a massive project that couldn't really fit in the 90-minute format I originally planned on. I had hours of championship gameplay footage alone—not to mention dozens of interviews with players and experts. I continued to work on it around the edges for several years, but focused on other projects as I tried to figure out how to complete this movie.Terry Purcell plays his then-beloved controller "Turd" during the championship.When the pandemic struck in March 2020, I found myself suddenly unemployed. I was working as a portrait photographer, which wasn't a high-demand job during lockdown.So I spoke with my friend Gilbert Tang, and he proposed a clear solution: This should be a documentary series. If we released it online to backers, there would be no need to cut it down to 90 minutes for a theatrical release. We would just make the episodes and release them as they were done.I also believe it's vital to add new game commentary from both Chris Tang and James Chen. (Tang was the lone commentator back in 2014.) They are onboard to record brand-new commentary for this series! The TeamChris Higgins (Director) - I'm a writer, podcaster, and filmmaker. I make my living telling true stories. You might know me from my reporting on This American Life (that was later adapted into a movie), my writing for Mental Floss magazine, my work writing and hosting the Election Ride Home podcast, my books, or whatever. I directed this movie, plus served in the camera and sound departments.Carl King (Editor & Original Score) - In the progressive rock world, Carl King has released albums under the names Sir Millard Mulch and Dr. Zoltan. He’s made music with Dweezil Zappa, Virgil Donati, Mike Keneally, Marco Minnemann, Travis Orbin, and others. His triple-CD concept album, HOW TO SELL THE WHOLE F#@!ING UNIVERSE TO EVERYBODY, ONCE AND FOR ALL! was co-released on Mimicry Records owned by Trey Spruance of Mr. Bungle. His favorite composers are Prokofiev, Stravinsky, and John Williams. Adam Cornelius, Vince Clemente, Trey Harrison (Producers) - The core team behind both the Classic Tetris World Championship (CTWC) itself and the previous Classic Tetris documentary, Ecstasy of Order, all worked on this project. Vince helped set up access to the event. Adam helped edit and organize footage. Trey digitized gameplay footage using his "Treyvision" system, turning fuzzy TV recordings into HD gameplay (more on that below).Josh Boykin (Narrator) - Josh Boykin is a game critic, streamer, narrator, and speaker who focuses on storytelling and narrative in games. As the Founder of Intelligame, he builds community around discussing all kinds of games and the connections players can make with the real world. He also carries a very pure, very strong love for Tetris Effect. You can find him on Twitter and you can find Intelligame on Twitter, Twitch, and Patreon.Chris Tang, James Chen (Commentators) - Chris Tang and James Chen have been part of the CTWC commentary team in recent years. Chen is a historian, advocate, and commentator for the Fighting Game Community. Tang is a game designer, eSports commentator, and recently appleared in the Netflix documentary High Score. He also coined the phrase "Boom! Tetris!"Lucy Bellwood (Audio Description Narrator) - Lucy Bellwood is a professional Adventure Cartoonist, author, and educator based in Portland, Oregon. Her work brings enthusiastic tales of exploration to thousands of readers online, in print, and in person. About the RewardsWhat if you don't ship to my country? I have set up shipping to 22 countries based on our understanding of the demographics of the CTWC player base and viewership—but I'm sure I have missed some! If your country isn't listed, please leave a comment and I will add it (unless there is some legal or other reason I simply cannot get there from here). You can also email Chris directly if you have questions or concerns.A classic CTWC shirt appears!REWARD: The Series — You'll be able to access a stream of the series, episode by episode, as it is released. How it works: You get a special code via email that lets you make a (free) account on the streaming service and grab new episodes (or old ones you may have missed). When new episodes come out, you get an email and can log in to watch them. I anticipate six episodes, with the first one coming out by April 2021.DIGITAL ADD-ON: Director's Commentary Streams — Taking a page from CGP Grey, I'll do live streams after each episode comes out. Tuning in to the live (or recorded) stream will require a secret link that you can only get if you've backed the appropriate level. Anyway, the stream involves me playing the episode, showing you the editing process, and bringing in special guests to talk about key moments and answering questions from y'all. If you're interested in behind-the-scenes stuff, or you just want to ask questions about the episode, this is for you. (Note: This add-on is available for every tier once you select your main reward. All the higher-priced reward tiers have it included, along with the series.)DIGITAL ADD-ON: Original Soundtrack — Download the original soundtrack by Carl King! If you like Tetris music, this is for you. Carl wrote and performed all the music you hear in the video for this project, and that's just the beginning.PHYSICAL ADD-ON: Stickers — This is a six-pack of vinyl stickers. They will come in various sizes, all with original designs related to the movie. I'm trying to keep them small enough to ship in a regular envelope, so expect most of these to be in the 3x3 inch size or thereabouts. I'll share designs as they're made.PHYSICAL ADD-ON: Original Polaroid from the Editing Suite — An original Polaroid photo taken by Director Chris Higgins. Each is unique, and will document some aspect of editing the film. All are taken on original Polaroid SX-70 cameras, and will have flaws common to Polaroids—the film might be a little messed up, focus might be slightly off, and so on. Have a piece of original art for not much money! Below are a few examples taken over the past few months. These are images taken at Chris's desk. (Chris also runs the Instagram account for Jamie Livingston, who was one of the most noteworthy Polaroid photographers of the 20th century!)Polaroid examples - a sealed ecosystem on Chris's desk (w/headphones), an early Instagram design, and a color-checker exposure testREWARD: Movie Poster — An 18x24 inch movie poster, signed by the Director, suitable for framing or hanging up in your dorm room. Keep in mind that this is smaller than the giant movie posters you see at movie theaters, but it's still a nice medium-sized poster printed on high-quality paper in full color. I'm still working with our designer on the imagery, but, you know, it'll look like a movie poster for a Classic Tetris documentary.REWARD: Blu-ray — A 1080p (HD) Blu-ray Disc with the full series, with the box signed by the Director. If that happens, y'all get that upgrade for free.REWARD: Classic Gaming Photo Book — As I mentioned above, I've worked as a photographer for years. I'll pick out the best ones and make a nice, hardbound book of them (rough page count—probably 30-ish, double sided printing). Because these books are costly to make and ship, this will be a very limited edition reward. And yes, I will sign and number them.REWARD: Chris Higgins Helps You — I do a lot of stuff, much of which you can find on my website. You get four hours of my time online for whatever (legal and morally acceptable) purpose we agree on. story:
Story Summary

In this gritty thriller, we spend the night with AMARIS -- young, softspoken, and 5 months pregnant -- and her manipulative boyfriend, RAFA, who tests her loyalty after forcing her to go on the run.

Impulso dives into the complexities of loving someone deeply while also being afraid to be around them. Amidst this conflict, Amaris must also think about a new life: her baby, and the family they can all become together. Set against the backdrop of an abusive relationship and gang violence, this film will highlight the pressures that face impoverished BIPOC individuals, as well as the curse of generational trauma, by following this family's horrific night.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1,600 in order to meet the basic demands of our production. This includes:

  • PRODUCTION DESIGN - Part of bringing our story to life in the most authentic way possible is creating the look of everything you see on screen. Our story takes place in the 2000s, so everything from our costumes to the type of car our characters drive is important in bringing the world to life on screen.
  • EQUIPMENT - We have an incredible team of filmmakers and we want to give them the best tools possible to create the most visually captivating film. This includes lenses, lighting, and other camera equipment to make our film as visually pleasing for our audience as possible.
  • CRAFT SERVICES - Our crew is a dedicated team of student filmmakers volunteering their time because they believe in this story. It is standard practice to provide one meal each shooting day to our amazing crew to make sure everyone is healthy and has the energy to create an incredible film.
  • ACTOR FEES - We strive to find the best talent possible to bring our characters alive. We plan on paying our actors and feel it is incredibly important to do so -- especially now, considering how the arts community has been impacted by the COVID pandemic.

If you're considering donating: thank you!!! 

  • We have some exciting perks to thank our donors! Just a few of the options you can choose from are: digital poster downloads, advanced screenings, and even Executive Producer credit. Check out the "Perks" section for a full list of offerings!

If we don't reach our fundraising goal, our production quality would drop significantly. We would never compromise feeding our team properly, nor paying our actors who need the support more than ever during these difficult times -- therefore, every dollar we don't make in our goal simply detracts from the vision our team's created for this intense, heartfelt story.

The Impact

Growing up in Chicago, I understand how impoverished Black, Indigenous, and People of Color tend to fall for the opportunities that gangs and criminal lifestyles provide. With the level of neglect and support from our own government, it can seem like the best option. Inevitably, however, these individuals suffer as a result -- along with their loved ones in many tragic cases. Through my filmmaking, and particularly through Impulso, I want to explore the lives of individuals facing these pressures while also acknowledging the impact of individual's choices.

Risks & Challenges

Our timeline is tight -- but with a script that I've been envisioning since last summer (and has minimal production demands), I have no doubt we'll be ready to roll if we meet our goal within our campaign length.

COVID-19 is a permanent concern, even with vaccines being distributed.  Our project, however, has a very small cast; there are only ever two people directly interacting in any given scene. In addition, our team members have had extensive experience producing films throughout the pandemic. We know the risk, but we also know how to minimize it as best we can.

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARING IS CARING! No, seriously. Even if you're not in a position to make a donation, spreading the word about this project and supporting our vision through social media traction will help expand the campaign's reach significantly. Tell your friends, tell your family: tell your uncle-twice-removed who's REALLY into thrillers. 

Starting and maintaining momentum upon launch is key.

story:
“Alex Jones: The Musical” follows a young, aspiring journalist in 1990’s Austin, Texas as he discovers the power of sensationalism.  After months of low audience engagement, Alex’s producer, Hillary, breaks the news that their “straight to the facts” political show is getting taken off of public access TV. The film opens on the night of their final broadcast with Alex determined to do whatever it takes to keep his show on the air.

 

I’ve always been fascinated by Alex Jones. His ability to make such outrageous claims and still maintain a loyal audience blows my mind. Since my freshman year of college, I've wanted to make an Alex Jones origin story; a fictional explanation for this larger-than-life personality (Anakin in the Star Wars prequels but Alex Jones.) Instantly, the comedic potential was clear, but when I started writing, I found an opportunity to comment on modern-day journalism in America.

As I started developing the concept, I decided that the best way to capture the spirit of Alex Jones was through a musical! Alex is charismatic and over the top in nature, what's a better way to express that than through song? The musical style combines a 90's alt-rock sound with the epic-ness of rock musicals like "Tommy" and "Rocky Horror."

For most of Jones’ career, he was known for his outrageous, but mostly harmless conspiracy theories. It wasn’t until he denied the Sandy Hook tragedy and obsessed over “Pizza-Gate” that his listeners took real-world actions, resulting in devastating consequences. I think Alex Jones is a cautionary tale for the dangers of competitive journalism. That’s why I want to tell this story. I believe this musical showcases the moral dilemma that many people with influence face: “Should I sacrifice what is right for an opportunity that could save my career?” For people like Alex Jones, that question is all too easy to answer.  
                                                                                                                  -Dru Miers (Director/Composer) 

   

    

We have wrapped on production! Now we need your help to cross the finish line! Your donation will help us with all the post-production expenses needed to get the film ready for festivals. These expenses include paying a professional sound designer/mixer, an orchestrator, VFX artists, and all film festival entry fees. 

Professional Sound Design/Mix

Sound is important in any film, but it’s really important in a musical. Having a professional sound mix will help showcase the amazing live vocals captured on set and create a soundscape that brings the entire film together. 

Orchestration/Accompaniment

We plan to record a live brass section to accompany the existing musical numbers. This requires paying a producer, musicians, and a studio space to record the additional instruments. 

VFX

In order to really sell that this films takes place in 1995, we need the "public access" footage from Alex’s show to appear authentic and fit in with the mid-90’s aesthetic.

Film Festival Entries

Last and certainly not least, your donation will go towards the pricey film festival entry fees. We believe this film could do very well in many festivals across Texas and the US. Because of the potential for the film to receive notoriety, we want to get it out to as many festivals as possible and we can’t do it without your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in the position to donate, PLEASE SHARE with your friends and family via social media and word-of-mouth! If you're not interested in perks, you can also make a direct donation via Venmo @druperman. 

Thank you so much for your support, sheeple!
story_txt:
“Alex Jones: The Musical” follows a young, aspiring journalist in 1990’s Austin, Texas as he discovers the power of sensationalism.  After months of low audience engagement, Alex’s producer, Hillary, breaks the news that their “straight to the facts” political show is getting taken off of public access TV. The film opens on the night of their final broadcast with Alex determined to do whatever it takes to keep his show on the air.
 


I’ve always been fascinated by Alex Jones. His ability to make such outrageous claims and still maintain a loyal audience blows my mind. Since my freshman year of college, I've wanted to make an Alex Jones origin story; a fictional explanation for this larger-than-life personality (Anakin in the Star Wars prequels but Alex Jones.) Instantly, the comedic potential was clear, but when I started writing, I found an opportunity to comment on modern-day journalism in America.
As I started developing the concept, I decided that the best way to capture the spirit of Alex Jones was through a musical! Alex is charismatic and over the top in nature, what's a better way to express that than through song? The musical style combines a 90's alt-rock sound with the epic-ness of rock musicals like "Tommy" and "Rocky Horror."
For most of Jones’ career, he was known for his outrageous, but mostly harmless conspiracy theories. It wasn’t until he denied the Sandy Hook tragedy and obsessed over “Pizza-Gate” that his listeners took real-world actions, resulting in devastating consequences. I think Alex Jones is a cautionary tale for the dangers of competitive journalism. That’s why I want to tell this story. I believe this musical showcases the moral dilemma that many people with influence face: “Should I sacrifice what is right for an opportunity that could save my career?” For people like Alex Jones, that question is all too easy to answer.                                                                                                                    -Dru Miers (Director/Composer) 
   

    
We have wrapped on production! Now we need your help to cross the finish line! Your donation will help us with all the post-production expenses needed to get the film ready for festivals. These expenses include paying a professional sound designer/mixer, an orchestrator, VFX artists, and all film festival entry fees. 
Professional Sound Design/Mix
Sound is important in any film, but it’s really important in a musical. Having a professional sound mix will help showcase the amazing live vocals captured on set and create a soundscape that brings the entire film together. 
Orchestration/Accompaniment
We plan to record a live brass section to accompany the existing musical numbers. This requires paying a producer, musicians, and a studio space to record the additional instruments. 
VFX
In order to really sell that this films takes place in 1995, we need the "public access" footage from Alex’s show to appear authentic and fit in with the mid-90’s aesthetic.
Film Festival Entries
Last and certainly not least, your donation will go towards the pricey film festival entry fees. We believe this film could do very well in many festivals across Texas and the US. Because of the potential for the film to receive notoriety, we want to get it out to as many festivals as possible and we can’t do it without your help.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you're not in the position to donate, PLEASE SHARE with your friends and family via social media and word-of-mouth! If you're not interested in perks, you can also make a direct donation via Venmo @druperman. 
Thank you so much for your support, sheeple!

story:
Summary

Help Camp Fire Ministries make the first annual Jesus Fest in Many, LA  Happen we are aiming for 6/6/2015.  100% of all Proceeds will go to fund the event which includes games concession and a live concert by Christian Rock band Kutless with special guest Sacred Warrior. 

What We Need:

details: 

( All perks will be honored upon booking confirmation and when ticket sales offically began.)

  • Cost for bringing in Kutless: $14,000 Broken into 2 payments of $7000 up front deposit needed no later than 04/14/2015 and another $7000 upon their arrival.  Transportation (requires a 15 passenger van and a cargo van) estimated $3000. RV for dressing room/production office estimate $1500. room, board, food and catering estimated $2000
  • Cost for Sacred Warrior:  $1500 broken up into $750 upfront and $750 upon arrival. Plane tickets $4000 trans transportation while in Louisiana $3000   room, board, and catering $2000. RV for dressing room estimated $1500
  • Cost of production (stage, sound, lighting, generators): $21,000
  • Cost of Fun and Games:  Estimated $15,800 includes room, board, and for the venders.
  • Cost of Insurance: $800/yr
  • Miscellaneous cost:  $34,700  this is for possible  unexpected cost as well if to cover things like security, staff, and anything extra that a may have been missed in the above prices for the event as there are many small details that are easy to miss but have to be in place for this to happen.  In the event any of this portion is unused it will be put either towards charity or a future event.

The Impact

With every dollar donated will be a step in reaching Many and the rest of Sabine Parish for Jesus Christ many lives can and will be changed by this event. There has never been an event of this magnitude in this area.

  • This event will open the door to help more of those in need in Sabine parish as proceeds generated from the event above and beyond the cost will go toward renovation of a house and the property it is on for the purpose to help those in need of food, clothing, shelter, and many other needs in this area.
  • As an Ordained minister and founder of Camp Fire Ministries it is my sole duty to make this event as honest and Godly as possible by making sure it is safe fun and beneficial to the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Prayer: This is the absolute biggest thing needed for this event. After all this event is about spreading the gospel of Jesus Christ.
  • Volunteering: We will need all the volunteers we can get.  
  • Food vender: We need as many food venders as we can get to come sell their food. We will not ask for upfront cost if you want come sell. Just a small 5% commission from your sells which will goto Camp Fire Ministries and other charitable ministries that help out with this event.
  • Spreading the news: Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks & God Bless you all.

story:
Contributors:  We prefer you pay via PayPal so that the team can access funds instantly.  Thank you.  

http://thediasporatravelshaiti.wordpress.com

Remembrance January 12, 2010 at 16:53 local Haitian Time marks the 5th Anniversary of the earthquake that took the life of more than 300,000 Haitians and changed the course of so many others in Haiti as well as in the diaspora around the world.

The Film explores Haitian Resilience.

The Diaspora Travels: Haiti

A feature documentary as well as a ongoing interactive digital project, which follows the Haitian Diaspora and their Reconstruction Efforts after the earthquake.

We began this journey November of 2010, our first production was 4 years ago February 2011.  We are about to take our second production trip.

We are not the press; we are the storytellers. In the documentary world, every dollar counts. There is no studio, there are no traditional financiers. We grab cameras and we go. We shoot until we can’t shoot anymore.

At the moment, we are on hold. We need to get moving as soon as we can and grab more of this footage. We are working with organizations in Haiti who are helping to rebuild the community and things are happening right now. We would like to tell this incredible story of a community left hanging in their greatest time of need.  We visit the areas of.

Our Blog is at: http://thediasporatravelshaiti.wordpress.com/

These are some initiatives that we are following.

Projects we are following:
https://ayitiini.wordpress.com/
http://sa-k-la-k-wel.org/
http://www.indyconvergence.org/haiti/

What are we going to use this raised funds for.

· Travel to on-location shoots

· Pay local film crew

·Equipment

·Post Production

.Transcription, Translation ( Kreyol, French)

Talk Backs and and focus group screening fundraisers

.Travel for the crew from City to City.

Support the Earthship Inspired Build 

Sa-K-La-K-Wel Community Centre
http://sa-k-la-k-wel.org/

.Tools

.Boots for Volunteers

.Support materials for the Build

You’ll notice that right now there are no traditional “perks” on the page, but this is not your traditional campaign. We literally need to pick up our cameras and go, and so we’re doing this as best as we can and as fast as we can.

We are COMMITTED TO USING THIS PROJECT TO INCITE SUSTAINABLE CHANGE and REBUILD a COMMUNITY.

If you are hoping for change too, would like to get involved in this amazing re-build of a tarnished community and we can do this together.

A docuvixen film has always aimed to create social justice and raise awareness through our projects. The work of this informs her work and to do this is to collaborate with as many artists as physically possible and to highlight the critical issues that face Haiti, Malinda was pressed to make a difference in the making of The Diaspora Travels to Haiti.

Contribute if you can, ever dollar helps. If you can’t contribute, please share this campaign on Facebook. Tweet it on Twitter. Email it to your friends.  We appreciate your support!

This project will be made with love. The rebuilding of a community can start now!

So this is the verbiage I used for the HUB FUNDRAISER 2015 @RootsReggaeHub

mail us at: thediasporatravelshaiti@gmail.com
Follow us on Twittter: @Diaspora2Haiti

Team:

Malinda Francis tells visual stories that derive from her experience, as well tries to communicate and connect with others within her community. An independent filmmaker, Malinda (a docuvixen film) has been working as a freelance filmmaker, camera operator and editor for 5 years now. She continues working on her own projects and various community media initiatives.The themes that she explores in her work are around urban living and cities, and as well migration stories. Her first independent poetic documentary Where are we (shot in Detroit) is currently going around in various festivals, and developing other films around urban cities such Windsor, especially in the advent of the economic crash.

Shana McCalla (co-producer): 

Shana is a Canadian filmmaker, writer and director. She is currently in development for multiple films, four being documentary driven, with social and humanitarian issues at the fore front. Her first short film Stain, a fictional drama; Co-Production with SmallAxx Motion Pictures, was released via the festival route in (2013). Later that year, she co-produced (Cocoon), a documentary about post-traumatic stress disorder and healing after tragedy. The film was made in collaboration with producer/director Karen Chapman and is currently still in production.  She has extensive experience in film financing, working for multiple independent Toronto-based production companies. Shana’s production company Salemscript Productions Inc., writes, directs and produces long-form documentaries focusing on communities, social justice, human rights, trauma and healing.  As well as, long-form fictional narratives and short films.  Shana is also a digital media producer, owning and operating an online radio station Roots Reggae Hub.  She has a keen eye and ear for talent and manages markets and promotes a roster of artists. Salemscript Productions Inc. areas of specialties are Television, Film and Digital Media Production Services, with a focus on top quality International Treaty-Co Productions. 

Michel Dessources, Jr (Co- Director/ Director of Photography). is a native Haitian born and raised in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Growing up as a young boy he was exposed to the arts. His father worked as a craft artist and his mother as a stage performing actress. Michel, having spent much quality time with his parents in and out of the home, developed an appetite for film and production. Subsequently, Michel attended Rockland Community College in Rockland County, New York where he received an Associates Degree in the Visual Arts. He went on to continue his studies at the Katherine Gibbs School of the Arts in New York City where he received his Bachelor of Arts degree in Visual Communications. He has since become a Photographer, a Graphic Designer and a Filmmaker. As a result of fulfilling his heartfelt passion for the arts through formalized education and training, Michel has received much notoriety in his brief career through the following assignments: Art Director with actor Danny Glover in 2004 at the Lincoln Center, Manhattan, New York. Art Director/Set Design for “Pluie d’Espoir” a movie directed by Jacques Roc. Director of a short documentary for the Bill Brookman Foundation, “UK,” and, last but not least, Art Director for Sensitization Projects for BDR/United Nations in Haiti. While all these are notable accomplishments, growing up in the streets of Port-au-Prince, Haiti exposed Michel to much more than the arts. He witnessed horror as a child observing the conditions of his native people. In the midst of this beautiful island tucked away in the Caribbean, Michel observed poverty and sickness to great magnitudes. He saw thousands of homeless people in the streets; sickness and disease that plagued the bodies of many; the hopelessness and despair of children with little to no formal educational opportunities; and of course, he witnessed the atrocious sexual and physical abuse of children that continues to burden his heart to this very day. As a result, through God’s guidance and covering, Michel has chosen to use film as his primary medium for sharing these dramatic, yet real images of life in his country with the world. After a number of years of wrestling and contemplating the idea, he is finally launching out; making strategic strides towards acquiring the necessary resources needed to secure his country in the same spiritual peace, educational freedom, and economic stability experienced by other nations throughout the world!

Oja Vincent, better known as DJ Oja, is a producer, DJ, educator and activist whose life work is to create, connect & be part of the global movement to build community through sound-based storytelling, music production, and performance while dynamically passing the tradition on to the next generation. University trained (at NYU and The Newschool) and self-taught in the music business and the art of electronic music production, he has been a part of the Earthdriver, a progressive live arts collective since 2002 (www.earthdriver.org) as the group’s dj/samplist, co-engineer, arranger and co-producer of two albums bearing the Earthdriver imprint (Sharrif Simmon’s “The Echo Effect” and “Earthdriver”). Sun Sound/Sunchild Productions, Oja’s DJ & production company, has been responsible for providing kinetic song selection/blends, sound design & ambiance for everything from live theatre performances (“Tongan Paint,” at Terra Nova Festival, “Osage Avenue” at Cherry Lane Theater & “Committing The Black On Black Crime Called Blackface,” sponsored by La Mama), fundraisers (for the people of Palestine, Hispaniola, Chiapas, ect.), live musical performances (3BB, Toni Blackman, Nemiss, DAM, Metrosonics & Brwn Bflo) festivals and conferences (CR10, USSJF2007, Red Hook Waterfront Festival, Clear Creek Festival), sound for Television and films (Sesame Street’s “Z is for Zipper,” PBS’s In the Mix series’ “Get the News?” “Dealing With Differences,” “Living With Change,” and “9-11: Looking Back….Moving Forward”) and co-producing two tracks from the soundtrack of Southeast Emmy winning Thorton Dial documentary “Mr. Dial Has Something to Say” to radio programs (89.1FM’s “The Subterrain” & “The Hip Hop Shop,” PNC radio’s “Show ‘n’ Prove” & WBMB 87.9FM’s “Homecookin” & “Pangea Radio”) and sound installations accompanying visual art (“Housing is a Human Right” with oral historians & photographers Mike Premo & Rachel Falcone and painter Leonardo Benzant’s exhibit “A Presence Under the Noise”). As an educator and program producer, Oja coordinated, developed curriculum (audio production and DJ instruction), and taught youth at the City Parks Foundation’s first ever free after school technology initiative program, Hook Productions, in Red Hook Brooklyn from February 2004 to September of 2008. The program has since been replicated at several sites around New York City. He also has taught semester-long media arts classes such as “So You Want To Be a DJ?” at Urban Arts Initiative, “Electronic Music Production 1.0” class at P.S.27 and “Beat Making 101” at P.S.15 (as a part of the Good Shepherd Summer Camp Program). Recently, Oja has been the coordinator/facilitator of The Red Hook Initiative’s “RHI Radio,” a youth produced radio program in Red Hook (www.rhicenter.org/rhiradio), helping get Red Hook’s youth-produced started with the eager teens from the Red Hook Initiative through out the school year and producing the First RHI Youth Radio Conference this summer. Presently, he continues to work to document, produce, collaborate, create and perform alongside like-minded artists in order to help tell untold stories, construct environments and inspire thought, dialog and action through sound. In addition, Oja has been using his community building and media arts skills to work with two partners to get their new non-profit organization, Lend a Hand and Foot (www.LAHAF.org) off the ground in efforts to aid the people of Haiti to build a new nation.

Juan Maluka ~ Marco ~ Line Producer/Camera Operator- Jacmel, Haiti
Born in Cap Haitian and a recent graduate of the Cine Institute in Jacmel, filmmaker.

story:
"KendoWa" / "剣道和"  

- Webumentary about Kendo Team Canada

What is this project about?

This story is about Team Canada, what makes a team. The dynamics of a team. Teamwork and team spirit.

An 8-Part, Episodic, Web-Series Video about Kendo 
We are creating possibly the first-ever "Webumentary" about Kendo. 

Kendo (剣道), is a modern Japanese martial art, which descended from swordsmanship and is widely practiced within Japan and many other nations across the world. Kendo is a physically and mentally challenging activity that combines martial arts practices and values with sport-like strenuous physical activity.

This story will focus on Team Canada and Kendo in Canada (past, present and future). This story needs a medium, this story needs to be told.  

Click here for a sample video 

Story

The vision, the belief and the power...sheer willpower. Everyone on the team and around the team makes a commitment. This story goes deeper, we look at Team Canada's past, present and future in wonderful cinematic online docu / #webumentary.     

How you can help 

  • Make a contribution. We are asking for contributions and donations from friends, family, dojos, supporters and corporate sponsors.
  • PLEASE use the Indiegogo share tools! They are really easy and help. (top left)
  • Recommend a sponsor to us or put us in touch with someone you may know.
  • PLEASE help us "spread the word" online, tell your connections, make some noise about this campaign. Let people know on social media.
    •  

The Perks 
See the perks (to the right of this page) for a breakdown of what You will receive for your contribution and involvement. 

Join us as we look into the past, present and future of Team Canada, Kendo in Canada and discover how it all started, where it is today and the future of Kendo in this 8-part, web-series video. The story is engaging and wonderfully visual.

By following the story of Team Canada, not only will we raise awareness of Kendo as a whole, we will also:

· Highlight the 100+ year history of Kendo in Canada;

· Pay tribute to the past 45 year history of Team Canada;

· Journey with Team Canada as they train to travel to Tokyo in May 2015 and compete in the 16th World Kendo Championships;
 

· Look into the future of Kendo in Canada and internationally;

· Strengthen cultural relationships between Canada and Japan; and

· Strengthen trade relationships between Canada and Japan through sponsorships and awareness.

 

Canada enjoys a very high profile within the global Kendo community with an impressive record of 2nd place x 2 times and 3rd place x 8 times at the World Kendo Championships (held every three years since 1970). Only teams from Japan, Korea, Brasil, Canada and USA have ever placed in the Top 2 over the WKC’s 40 year history. 


Why should you support us? 

Your contribution and support will help us to tell this much needed story and will help promote Kendo on a global level to a new younger audience. 
In recent years more video has become available online through Youtube and via social media networks such as Facebook, this has added to the interest, growth and development of Kendo. We hope Kendo friends and the Kendo community globally will join us in helping promote kendo to the next generation. 


The Details

Filming has already begun and more filming / production is required prior, during and after the 16th World Kendo Championships. (please see example videos) Your support will help us to create better content and higher quality footage. 

Production and editing will continue until Oct 12, 2015. 

Each episode will last approximately 5 minutes and will be released as a DVD and will be released online through social media during the Fall/Winter of 2015. 

In addition to crowdfunding, we are also approaching select Canadian and Japanese brands and companies for assistance and corporate sponsorships.  


Location: Filming  and Production will take place mostly in Canada and will use footage from the 16th World Kendo Championships, Tokyo, Japan.
Post production and editing will take place in Canada.  
We will also be collecting video files and testimonials from friends, supporters and the worldwide kendo community. Video from past WKC events and also personal testimonials are something we encourage. Contact us, if interested in submitting . 


*please note* Funding raised here is for the kendo video project only.
To donate directly to Team Canada please click here

Thank YOU!

This project could not be made without the support and help of our friends, family, the Kendo community and our sponsors. We would like to give our thanks and show our appreciation to the following individuals, communities, businesses and groups: 

A Special Thank You to the following companies: 
National Bank
MISC Media
Panasonic 
Kendo World
Seneca School of Communication Arts
Adobe 
IAMSTATIC 
Impact Music 
Shutterstock

Many Thanks to the following kendo communities: 
Team Canada 
Canadian Kendo Federation
Kendo Ontario
Kenshi 24/7
World Kendo Network  

A Very Special Thank You to the following individuals for their much appreciated support and guidance:  
Bryan Asa, Shigemitsu Mitch Kamata, Alex Bennett, Christian D'Orangeville, Shigeo Kimura, Hyun-June Choi, Ray Murao, Matthew Raymond, Marisa Iacobucci, Patrick Barfoot, Rob Butterwick, Sumit Bahtia, Kelvin Ip, Tuan Anh Hoang, Elliott Altilia, Nico Bergeron, Paul Eric Marko, Abdal Hoosein, 

Thank You to the following individuals for their much appreciated support: 

Anthony Walker, Geoff Salmon, George McCall, Ginga Teishikata, Ryo Bobby Yasumura, Ryo Tamaru, Samuel Cappiello, Steve Quinlan,

Thank You to the following Dojos for their much appreciated support: 
JCCC Kendo, Jung Ko Kendo Academy, Kingston Kendo Club, McGill University Kendo Club,  Renbu Dojo, Stevenston Kendo Club, Toronto Kendo Club, University of Toronto Kendo Club, Markham Kendo Club,
Get in touch. Join the Facebook group. We look forward to adding you to our list. 

BREAKDOWN OF FUNDS

 Your contribution will benefit the following areas: 

- Director, Exec producer & Production assist. DoP. camera ops 
- associated expenses & costs inc.; telecoms, insurance, materials, etc. 
- Equipment Rental, i.e cameras, lighting, cables, memory storage etc. 
- Travel inc, per diems, accommodation, etc. 
- Post production, editing, grading, motion graphics. 
-  PR, communications, social media promotion
- Sound design, creative / art direction, development, design 
- Copywriting services inc. script, subtitles, translations etc. 
- MISC costs i.e storyboarding, printing, postage, accounting, transfer, memory storage, hosting, files & asset management etc. 

What is "Wa"? 
Wa (和) is a Japanese cultural concept usually translated into English as "team harmony", some say it is one of the most fundamental concepts of Japan's moral system. The concept of Wa is fundamental in the practice of Kendo. 

It implies a peaceful unity and conformity within a group, in which members prefer the continuation of a harmonious community over their personal interests.

What is a "Webumentary" ? 
It is similar to a TV documentary, however, not in the traditional documentary sense. The video will be a series of 8 episodes released online via social networks and online groups. Hence, this makes it a "webumentary". 

What is Kendo? 

Kendo, the Japanese "way of the sword", is a very powerful visual medium.

Kendo is steeped in history and tradition and is a joy to watch, the world championship team events are exciting to say the least. It takes years of dedication and training to perform at this level. 

The All Japan Kendo Federation (AJKF) estimates that the number of "kendoka" in Japan is 1.66 million, with over 6 million practitioners worldwide, 


Why is it being made? 

We believe this video project will help promote the practice of Kendo globally.

We strongly believe this video project will contribute to the development of culture and promote peace and prosperity among all people.

Kendo practitioners all around the world already experience and foster a sense of "Wa", a peaceful unity within the global Kendo community, this helps kendo to grow. The kendo community around the world is one of peace and friendships. 

Thank you for reading. Thank you for being involved. 


"If there is effort, there is always accomplishment." - Jigoro Kano. 


#KendoCanada #16wkc #劍道 #Kendo #KendoWa #剣道和
