story:
KEN - THE MOVIE  is a new film project by award-winning writer-director Claudia Rorarius. The musician Ken Stringfellow (The Posies, R.E.M., Big Star) will play the lead character in his first ever acting role. 

After an intense process of research and development, the main cast is assembled, the story has come together, and we are ready to go! Shooting is scheduled in the US for autumn 2016 and spring 2017 — dates that can’t come soon enough.

KEN - THE MOVIE grew from Claudia Rorarius' desire to work with a particular person — Ken Stringfellow. And yes, the real life Ken and the film’s protagonist share the same name, but this is no documentary. Rather, Ken Stringfellow acts as himself, reliving parts of his life and fraying the line between reality and fiction in the process.

The story follows Ken on a tour through the US. It’s a road he’s travelled a thousand times before, but on this occasion his world is turned upside-down. The towns appear deserted, his shows are going badly, and his nerves are at breaking point. One morning he wakes to find his voice gone — an event that sends him over the edge, plunging into a catastrophic breakdown. Stranded and distressed, he is haunted by the memory of his bodily mother abandoning him as a child. After deciding he's had enough emotional torment, he takes fate into his own hands and begins the search for his lost mother, taking a long and painful road back to life.

KEN - THE MOVIE will deploy the same experimental techniques of Claudia’s previous films. As events from Ken's real life intertwine with fictional elements, the genres of documentary and fiction fade away in the revelation of an intimate new form of cinema.

The innovate potential of this movie, though, cannot be realised without your support. Everything depends on this first stage. If we reach our initial targets and everything goes well, we will extend the campaign. The momentum and support of this first phase will also impact our ability to secure public funding.

KEN - THE MOVIE brings together a team of award-winning filmmakers, musicians, cinematographers, and actors. 

Claudia Rorarius' last film, Chi l'ha Visto - Who Saw Him, was nominated for Best Performance, Best Director, and Best Movie at the Torino Film Festival in 2009. It was also selected for many more festivals, such as the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival, the Montréal World Film Festival, and Film Festival Max Ophüls. Critics have called it "intensive", "touching", and "grand cinema". Her work grapples with how we understand ourselves, illuminating dark corners of identity and despair while raising questions for the nature of filmmaking itself.

Ken Stringfellow's life is music. A founding member of the legendary Seattle indie-pop band The Posies, Ken also played a part in the reformation of Big Star, one of the most influential bands in pop history. He has also toured with R.E.M. for 10 years, assisted with their albums “Reveal” and “Around the Sun,” and in 2005 he founded the garage rock band The Disciplines. More recently Ken has worked as a songwriter and producer for acts like Lagwagon, Damien Jurado, The Long Winters, Snow Patrol, Neil Young, Patti Smith, Mudhoney, and Death Cab For Cutie. To date, his discography spans over 200 albums. A recent solo record, 2012’s Danzig in the Moonlight, was warmly received by critics.

Although Ken was featured in Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me, a documentary about the infamous power-pop band, KEN - THE MOVIE will be his first acting role. In the film, you can expect to see Ken do what he does best: captivate us with his heartfelt songs. But the film also shows what lies on the other side of those songs, probing into his life and bringing his fears and vulnerabilities to the surface.

Intense, uncompromising, and challenging, our film isn't the kind of thing that investors flock to. But honestly, we wouldn't have it any other way. So, out on our own, trying to do something different, we are looking for your support.

Supporting this project has a special benefit: with this commitment you will help to recognize, develop, and actively promote the unique vision of women in the film industry. By getting KEN - THE MOVIE finished, we hope to inspire many more female directors to pick up a camera and get out there.

Throughout her career, Claudia has battled her way through the gender bias of the film business. As a member of Pro Quote Regie, the biggest women's director movement in Germany, she plays an active role in the promotion of women in film. Jane Campion gets to the heart of the issue, saying, "Without [women] writing and being directors, the rest of us are not going to know the whole story."

Filmmaking is a collaborative process. We're working hard to create the best work in the most economical fashion. All donations will go straight into the various costs associated with the making and airing of KEN - THE MOVIE.  These include equipment rentals, travel and transportation, and general production costs. Here's a diagram of what we need for the film:

Firstly, perks. We have an amazing range of special offers for you to choose from. Ken Stringfellow has cleared the path to his back-catalogue where you can choose your favorite album, which he will sign with a personalized message! Claudia Rorarius has put her experience as a photographer and director on the table, offering you a chance to meet and discuss whatever is on your mind.


And, if you're a true lifetime Ken Stringfellow fan, he's even agreed to perform private concerts for you and your friends. Of course, there's many things in-between, ranging from an advanced copy of the film to a personalized music video. Check the righthand side of the page for a full list of the exciting perks!


With your support, we'll be spending the upcoming months making the movie. While the film is in development, Claudia and Ken will be keeping you up to date on their progress through Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and their website.

We're excited for you, our precious friends and fans, to be a part of it all. 

CLAUDIA RORARIUS (WRITER/DIRECTOR/PRODUCER)

Claudia Rorarius is the driving force behind KEN - THE MOVIE. A dedicated and insightful filmmaker, she has also photographed artists like Kelis, Rufus Wainwright, Vivienne Westwood, Eminem, Pharrell Williams, Jamie XX, and John Cale, publishing in magazines like SPEX, INTRO, WIRE and Wallpaper. While she was studying at the Academy of Media Arts Cologne, she worked on the short films CABLE CAR and TWIN, both of which received international awards. CHI L'HA VISTO-WHO SAW HIM (available online), Claudia's first feature-length film, premiered in 2009 to wide acclaim and was selected for the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival, the Montréal World Film Festival, and Film Festival Max Ophüls.  www.claudiarorarius.com, Claudia on IMDb.

KEN STRINGFELLOW (MAIN CAST)

Ken Stringfellow is one half of The Posies, the legendary indie-pop band from Seattle. The band has enjoyed a long and successful run, winning the hearts of critics and crowds from all over the world. From 1993 onward, Ken has played a part in the reformation of Big Star, one of the most influential bands in pop history. He’s also toured with R.E.M. for 10 years, and assisted with the albums “Reveal” and “Around the Sun.” More recently he has worked as a songwriter and producer for acts like Lagwagon, Damien Jurado, The Long Winters, Snow Patrol, Neil Young, Patti Smith, Mudhoney, and Death Cab For Cutie. The Posies album Solid States was just released earlier this year and has been warmly received by critics all over the world. www.kenstringfellow.com.
Ken Stringfellow is no stranger to the movie business. In the mid-nineties he contributed to the soundtracks from The Basketball Diaries and Reality Bites. More recently, he was featured in Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me. Ken on IMDb

KIM TAYLOR (MAIN CAST)

Kim Taylor is a musician, songwriter, and actress. She has crafted five beautiful solo albums and toured extensively with acts like Ron Sexmith, Over the Rhine, and Kris Kristofferson. Her songs have been featured in numerous television shows like Flashpoint, Army Wives, Smallville, Cyberbully, and One Tree Hill, and most recently in the UK comedy-drama Stella. Her acting debut came in 2013 on Matt Porterfield’s I Used To Be Darker, where she portrayed a musician and mother struggling through a divorce. The film was selected for the Sundance Film Festival and the Berlinale, and it has won numerous awards. www.kim-taylor.net

LIZA CRAMER (PRODUCER)

Liza Cramer will help produce and manage KEN - THE MOVIE. Liza has been working as the Unit Manager, Assistant Producer, Production Coordinator and translator for national and international productions since 2009.  She was part of the production team of the internationally acclaimed THE STRANGE LITTLE CAT (2013), recent Sundance success MORRIS FROM AMERICA (2016), and she was also a member of the Berlin-based independent production company credo:film (2012-2014). Liza studied American Studies in Berlin, Nashville, and Paris. She focused on contemporary culture, film, and media, receiving her master’s degree in 2007. In 2012, she completed Germany's Production Manager state certificate for film and TV, achieving the best result of her class. 


HAJO SCHOMERUS (DOP)

Hajo Schomerus is a dedicated cinematographer. He has worked on both documentary and fiction projects, and the films he has shot have gained wide recognition, including a Best Cinematography award from the Cairo Film Festival for Magic Eye, a co-produced Albanian feature, and the German Critics Association's Best Documentary Award in 2011 for his documentary IN MY FATHER'S HOUSE ARE MANY MANSIONS. His films have been shown at festivals around the world, like his recent works 10 Billion and The Barber and The Bomb, which are currently touring the festival circuit. 

Even if you can't contribute funds, you can still be a part of our journey. Any help is hugely appreciated, and you can do this simply by sharing.

For a start, there's a list of links to the left of this page that share the Indiegogo campaign, and a simple click of one of these buttons would be a great help for us.

We are also on:
  • Facebook,
  • Twitter,
  • Instagram,
  • and we have a Blog.
Through these various platforms you can join us on our journey to make the film. We will be posting regular updates, giving you little peaks into the production process, and offering even more special perks for the supporters of the film. 
So, join us, in whatever way you can!

We truly appreciate your support.

CLAUDIA RORARIUS  (director) + KEN STRINGFELLOW  (main cast)

__________

A big thanks to all the kind people who have helped the campaign so far:

  • Campaign manager: Wolfgang Gumpelmaier (gumpelmedia)
  • Campaign and text editor:  Ben Barlow
  • Videos: Ralf Krämer, Jeroen Schriks, Birgit Möller
  • Editors: Silke Botsch, Claudia Rorarius
  • Sound: Jan Ralske
  • Photographers:  Alison Cornish, Bootsy Holler, Bruno Pélican, Connie Freestone, Daiana Seijo, Hanneke Wetzer, Jamie Williams, JB Meijers, Juan Perez-Fejardo,  Niffer Calderwood, Sami Mikkola
  • Designer: Christoph Gabriel  
  • Thanks: Kim Voynar
story_txt:
KEN - THE MOVIE  is a new film project by award-winning writer-director Claudia Rorarius. The musician Ken Stringfellow (The Posies, R.E.M., Big Star) will play the lead character in his first ever acting role. After an intense process of research and development, the main cast is assembled, the story has come together, and we are ready to go! Shooting is scheduled in the US for autumn 2016 and spring 2017 — dates that can’t come soon enough.KEN - THE MOVIE grew from Claudia Rorarius' desire to work with a 
particular person — Ken 
Stringfellow. And yes, the real life Ken and the film’s 
protagonist share the same name, but this is no documentary. 
Rather, Ken Stringfellow acts as himself, reliving parts of his life and fraying the line between reality and fiction in the process.The story follows Ken on a tour through the US. It’s a road he’s 
travelled a thousand times before, but on this occasion his world is 
turned upside-down. The towns appear deserted, his shows 
are going badly, and his nerves are at breaking point. One morning he 
wakes to find his voice gone — an event that sends him over the edge, 
plunging into a catastrophic breakdown. Stranded and distressed, he is haunted by the memory of his 
bodily mother abandoning him as a child. After deciding he's had enough emotional torment, he takes fate into his own hands and begins the search for his lost mother, taking a long and painful road back to 
life.






KEN - THE MOVIE will deploy the same experimental techniques of Claudia’s previous films. As events from Ken's real life intertwine with fictional elements, the genres of documentary and fiction fade away in the revelation of an intimate new form of cinema.
The innovate potential of this movie, though, cannot be realised without your support. Everything depends on this first stage. If we reach our initial targets and everything goes well, we will extend the campaign. The momentum and support of this first phase will also impact our ability to secure public funding.






KEN - THE MOVIE brings together a team of award-winning filmmakers, musicians, cinematographers, and actors. 

Claudia Rorarius' last film, Chi l'ha Visto - Who Saw Him, was nominated for Best Performance, Best Director, and Best Movie at the Torino Film Festival in 2009. It was also selected for many more festivals, such as the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival, the Montréal World Film Festival, and Film Festival Max Ophüls. Critics have called it "intensive", "touching", and "grand cinema". Her work grapples with how we understand ourselves, illuminating dark corners of identity and despair while raising questions for the nature of filmmaking itself.

you will help to recognize, develop, and actively promote the unique vision of women in the film industry. By getting KEN - THE MOVIE finished, we hope to inspire many more female directors to pick up a camera and get out there. 


Throughout her career, Claudia has battled her way through the gender bias of the film business. working hard to create the 
best work in the most economical fashion. All donations will go straight into the various costs

We're excited for you, our precious friends and fans, to be a part of it all.

story:
Hello Global Community :)

My name is Gio Miranda Coelho Junior, and I am the Executive  Director for Neo Evolutionary Logic Project (NEVLO Project).


Since 2013, I have been steadily building on ideas whose goal is to provide a free classroom with a team of professionals on all subjects sustainable. Whether it's is building your home, growing and cooking your own food, making your own clothes, or trying to stretch your body and expand your intelligence, these are all concepts that can be attained sustainably for a more permanent culture that serves us, our children and their children's children.

In order to do this, I combined multiple industries such as art, psychology and kinesthetic learning and formed "Armone Galaxy", a revolutionary life-sized human board game. This concept has taken me 11 years to forge, and with the love and support of so many all over the world, I am finally bringing it to reality. I believe this board game will help humanity and provide them with powerful tools that promote balance, intelligence, and social alliances.

So what is Armone Galaxy? In 2013, we raised the funds to construct a 36-foot geodesic dome. This year we will commence phase II and construct a 5-circuit labyrinth around the dome. [SEE IMAGE ABOVE]


At Burning Man, installations such as these are allocated plenty of real estate for the cost of one ticket. This serves as an excellent location for experimental research as it not only provides the space but also some of the harshest weather conditions on earth, And 60,000 participants from all over the world who get to interact with the installation.


This is my life's work. I have a 5 year plan to bring Armone Galaxy to its final evolution. Each year I will return to Burning Man until the final phases are complete. By 2020 or before, it is my goal to bring Armone Galaxy to the world outside Burning Man.

But it starts now, and it starts with your support!


BUDGET BREAKDOWN:

With the funds raised this year, the interior and exterior of the dome, the erection of the labyrinth and a slew of safety equipment will be purchased and preserved for the lifespan of this project.


BUDGET 1: BARE BONES

$7540    -   MATERIALS & EQUIPMENT

Grommet 117
Fastener Chains 200
Fastener Carabiners 113
Fabric for Walls 991
Metal Stakes 1691
Plywood  876
2x4x96 Studs 1115
Screws 160
Paint 300
Resin 100
LED Solar Rope Lights 336
LED Spotlights 272
Mailbox 18
Armone Flag 50
Printing 100
Electric Socket Wrench 230
Electric Drills 200
Grommet Press 276
Extension Cords 100
Stake Driver 100
Stake Puller 100
Sledgehammers
 95


BUDGET 2:

$600        -   1 YEAR STORAGE FEE  FOR MATERIALS & EQUIPMENT

$1580      -   TICKETS/FOOD/SHELTER/RESOURCES FOR 3 WEEKS

$900       -   TRUCK TRANSPORT & FUEL

=$3,080


BUDGET 3: UPGRADES TO DOME

FLOORING 945
CLIMBING NET 1785
ROPE FOR NET 331
SLACKLINE W/KIT 394
GYMNASTIC MAT 1195
TRAMPOLINE 64
BEAN BAGS 198
SCAFFOLDING 848
LADDER 160
= $5920

BUDGET 4: BURNING MAN THEME DECORATIONS & RECORDING EQUIPMENT
 
CARNIVAL MIRRORS 177
GOPRO 399
GOPRO DISKS 150

= $726

The Impact

When this project is completed, it will have served 7 years of people from all over the world. They will spread the word and students from all over the world will come to learn from the ARMONE GALAXY BOARD GAME. And classes held inside the dome will provide students with information on how to create their life more sustainably. This SCHOOL will be a powerhouse of knowledge, self-empowerment, and community building!

I have traveled the globe in search of this knowledge, spent my life working and earning this knowledge, and through a nonprofit will provide it to ALL OF YOU, BECAUSE IT IS FOR OUR FUTURE.


Risks & Challenges

As this process has begun, it is highly open to evolution. And that is the premise of NEVLO, to build neo evolutionary logic based on what has already been learned: It is a revolution of never giving up your quest for knowledge and truth. With that said, I am NOT ALONE. Of course things will change and could be risky. Nothing ever goes EXACTLY to plan, but it's having enough self-awareness, intelligence and flexibility to circumnavigate adaptively. There are supporters in the dozens from countries globally that WANT THIS TO HAPPEN JUST LIKE YOU. No matter how close or far we come this year to our goal, we will continuously strive to achieve its full evolution. After all, like I said, THIS IS MY LIFE'S WORK! My team and I are never going to give up, because the knowledge that is to be taught MUST SURVIVE FOR OUR FUTURE.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please don't feel discouraged or disengaged from this project. Just because you can't provide numerical digits from your bank account, does not mean you cannot contribute with your voice and heart. PLEASE SHARE THIS! LET PEOPLE KNOW WHAT IS COMING; WHAT TO EXPECT!


THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR VISITING AND SUPPORTING!


WITH MASSIVE LOVING REGARD,


G i o , Executive Director

ARMONE GALAXY 1.0 - 2015

N.Ev.Lo. Project

story:
Tyger! Tyger! burning bright 
In the forests of the night, 
What immortal hand or eye 
Could frame thy fearful symmetry?        The Tyger, by William Blake


The Story

My name is Jasia Armstrong Kaulbach, I grew up in downtown Philadelphia and I have lived and pursued my dream of directing films in New York City, Massachusetts, the Maryland coast and now, London.  I am currently finishing an MA in film directing at Met Film School based out of the Ealing Studios.  

Tyger, Tyger is a script written by my fellow Met Film student, Pedro Brum.  Pedro is in the screenwriting program at Met and hails from Brazil.  When I read Pedro's script, it pulled me in immediately.  Tyger Tyger is an engaging coming of age tale with a surreal twist and vibrant characters, and I am extremely excited to direct it. The films follows Tyger in her home city of Brighton during two life changing days, in which she clashes with her controlling parents at home, meets a gang of misfits who uses their fire to create havoc, and learns that even those who she thought least likely to burn, turn out to have turbulent inner fires of their own.  This story urges the audience to question the way in which we deal with our inner anger and emotion, and to understand that everyone has their own battles large and small.  

Your help will be paramount to the production of Tyger Tyger.  We have an amazing script, cast and crew all set to go into production.  With the necessary funding, together we can bring Tyger's story to life.

#JOINTYGER

The Team

Our cast and crew are talented, enthusiastic, professional, and absolutely committed to making Tyger Tyger a fantastic film. 

Abby Cassidy will play Sasha, Tyger's partner in crime and best friend.  Abby has performed with the National Theatre and many parts in short films and TV programs.

Shannon Hayes will play Tyger.  Shannon has had main roles on several BBC programs and short films and is vibrant on screen, perfectly capturing the grit and vulnerability of Tyger's character.  

The producer, Carey Thring has recently produced a short film 'City Lights', chosen to be supported by FilmLondon.  The Director of Photography, Laura Gallop has worked on countless short films and a beautiful style of cinematography.  The VFX artist, Jean Marc Chappelle has already been invaluable in bringing the fire from the the page to the screen. The music composer, Emma Williams is developing a score that will serve to drive the film's mood and style.

We only need one thing to make this real: your help. If we get the funding, we will be able to maintain the entire crew during the full 5 days of shooting and we will have access to film equipment,  transportation, locations, and post-production effects. Whether it's a small or large sum, we will be extremely thankful for your contribution.  And you will become part of the process: making a great film! 

Join  #TEAMTYGER, and you will also receive PERKS! Read more about what is included with each reward on the right side of this page! 

Also- by joining us, you will not only get our special rewards, you will also be involved in an exciting film that will be submitted to film festivals around the world.

#JOINTYGER

Why we need your help!

So why do we need the funding? 
We calculate that we will be a total of 15 crew members, including the actors, the sound department, the photography department, the art department, the director, the producer, the script supervisor, the first assistant director, and the runners. We will be shooting for 5 days in London and Brighton. 

THE BREAK-DOWN:
- Costumes, Make-Up, Props- Estimated 300 POUNDS
- Expenses for food, transportation and accommodation for all the crew members. Estimated 1000 POUNDS
 - Camera, sound and light equipment. Estimated 1000 POUNDS
-  Locations- Boarding School, Family house, Beach, Exterior street scenes. Estimated 500 pounds
-  Cast - 5 main actors. Estimated 700 pounds
-  Crew. Estimated 500 pounds


Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute to the funding, please get the word out and make some noise about Tyger Tyger with family, friends, at work, anywhere! Our official hashtag is #JOINTYGER - in any post you share via Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, etc. make sure to add that.
  • Join our Facebook group and share it- We will be posting updates, photos and videos as production develops!  https://www.facebook.com/groups/1538236033065488/

story:
Thank you for your support of my ‘Finalist Challenge’.

Funds raised through the challenge, will go towards the ‘Finalist Challenge Episode’ of: ‘Hustle Girls Show’. On that episode the cast members will collectively present checks to several nonprofit Organizations, in addition to working as a team to feed the hungry, & homeless in our Communities.

*Perks will be provided upon completion of this 'Finalist Challenge'.

story:
First the screenplay was born in 2006, then the graphic novel in 2012, now, with your help, this unique tale will finally become a movie.



Hello Folks,

My name is Christopher Garetano and I want to cordially invite you to be part of a unique motion picture experience called South Texas Blues.

I'm primarily a movie maker, and I recently completed my second picture, Montauk Chronicles. (See the trailer and additional information, at the links below)

MONTAUK CHRONICLES : MOVIE TRAILER

MONTAUK CHRONICLES: OFFICIAL WEBSITE

I'm here today to tell you all about a project that is so close to my heart, it haunts me.

It's as if the very project itself calls to me. It's a powerful entity. It's been in my mind for twenty-years and in-development for almost ten years. I feel its energy often, like a large magnet drawing me in.

I cannot resist any longer.

South Texas Blues is one part fantasy, one part history and one part insanity.

It's the kaleidoscopic story of "TOBE",  an independent film director who battles environmental elements, time, and his own demons during the mysterious summer of 1973.

It takes place during the creation one of the most infamous horror movies in history, "Saturn In Retrograde" (which ultimately became The Texas Chain Saw Massacre) and "Tobe" has no idea of what he's about to unleash into the world.

Tobe and the crew of "Saturn In Retrograde" must climb great and dangerous heights to complete the movie.  The Texas heat, sleep deprivation, lack of money, the ticking clock and each other are only the small obstacles in their way.

[Have a look at an early SOUTH TEXAS BLUES "Pitch-Film" (below) that was used to court potential investors from 2006 - 2012.]


In 2012, after many ups and downs regarding funding, I (along with Illustrator Trevor Cook) carefully translated my original screenplay into the graphic novel form. Trevor did a wonderful job of translating my vision to the comic book form.

  The South Texas Blues: Graphic Novel was published, and serialized, in Fangoria Magazine throughout 2012.

SOUTH TEXAS BLUES : NEWS POST # 1

SOUTH TEXAS BLUES : NEWS POST #2


I decided to put the STB movie project aside to make my next motion picture, Montauk Chronicles. I promised myself that I would return to South Texas Blues when the time was right.

 


Making Montauk Chronicles was an odyssey not unlike the one that "TOBE" experiences in South Texas Blues.

I pushed myself further and harder than I ever had in my life and it was the greatest challenge that I've experienced to this date.

As soon as I completed post-production on Montauk Chronicles, I immediately realized it was time to make South Texas Blues. I knew I was ready.


I sharpened my skills to a razor edge as I personally handled most major tasks (Including writing, producing, directing, cinematography, visual effects and editing) in the creation of the entire feature-length movie.

I had to learn to be economical, think quickly and work with a small cast and crew.

The entire budget was far under $30,000.

Montauk Chronicles is now a success and it's currently reaching a growing world-wide audience.

INTERVIEW WITH CHRISTOPHER ON AOL NEWS

INTERVIEW WITH CHRISTOPHER ON COAST TO COAST AM


During the making of Montauk Chronicles. I certainly learned how to handle the logistics, people, and technical aspects of a large, complicated movie project but I also learned what "TOBE" was going through while making "Saturn In Retrograde."

I understand his odyssey at a molecular level and I'm ready to go to war.

I'd like to recruit YOU to be part of this very special "platoon" and I'm going to make this wild and beautiful ride one you will never forget.

We invite you to be a "micro-producer" for White Phosphorus Pictures. Your contribution (of $25 dollars or more) will allow you full access to the South Texas Blues screenplay as well as a constant window into our production (via-a special VIMEO link) where you will view the making of from the beginning to the very end of post-production.
Even the smallest (Ten-dollar) donation will allow you access to the screenplay but we designed a variety of more amazing gifts for higher investing "micro-producers."

Every week, from pre-production on to the completion of South Texas Blues you will have access to a behind the scenes window through a chronological series of short documentaries and vignettes.




Making Montauk Chronicles I learned to be efficient, economical and extremely creative with very little.
No dollar will be wasted (making South Texas Blues) as I have plans for very specifically scheduled Pre-Production and Production working days where no one will be on set that isn't involved in something significant.
My personal philosophy on movie making is that it's an illusion. So to create an illusion it requires more ingenuity and experience than money.
The show is meant to be on the screen, and NOT on the set.
If you're a good illusionist you can make gold from dust.
I often wondered why on larger shoots that I've witnessed, the production management felt it necessary to hire more people than they need and rent/buy more equipment than was ever needed. I've also noticed a waste of money on transportation, food, lodging etc.
If we're shooting a scene that requires five people on set, then five people will be on set.  If one person is needed to shoot an insert-shot than that's who will be working that day.
This method of thinking was how I was able to keep the budget below $30,000 for Montauk Chronicles and save a great deal of time.
We will be living in Austin, Texas, for the duration of the production, and a large portion of our cast and crew will be hired locally i.e. saving money on transportation and lodging. We're also looking for eager interns and faithful devotees for days where we need a little extra help.
I'm confident that the $80,000 that we're seeking on INDIEGOGO, will bring us to a very significant place in our journey and most likely well in to post production.
I'm personally going to handle the remaining financing.
We're currently securing a dedicated group of artists who, over the years, have expressed their adamant interest in being part of South Texas Blues. Our cast and crew are more interested in creating a solid motion picture than receiving a big paycheck.
The money that we're raising on INDIEGOGO will be a significant portion of our general budget.
We're going to get to work right away, and our first location scouts in Austin, Texas are set for October 2015. October 2015 also marks the very first of our behind the scenes communication with our "Micro-Producers."
To remain economical, several members of our production crew are wearing multiple hats. Your contributions are in great hands. Everyone involved has experience and are all integral contributors of successfully completed and distributed motion pictures.
Below is a general breakdown of our budget and please understand, through our previous experience, we know how to use the money wisely.

South Texas Blues is larger in scale, than Montauk Chronicles so we're going to need a bit more to accomplish our goal but we can still keep the budget considerably low using the same production ethics.

1. Pre-Production:  (Between October 2015-February 2016)

Estimated budget $35,000

We plan to begin principal photography on South Texas Blues in late March of 2016.  Before we begin shooting we must first spend several solid months of careful pre-production and planning.
Pre Production Includes but is not limited to:
 Location scouting & securing locations, travel, production design, visual and make-up effects design and testing, casting and rehearsal, costumes, securing equipment and props, storyboards, hiring and securing the remainder of our crew and organizing all other logistics regarding the forthcoming production of South Texas Blues. 
In addition, during several of our location visits, we will save a great deal of time by shooting exterior establishing shots, sunsets, Astro-time-lapse photography, environments, and landscapes that are all unique to Texas. I find that this is a job that requires no more than a crew of two people, and this footage can come in very useful later in the editing.

2. Production (Between March and May of 2016)

Estimated Budget $40 -$60,000


We are designing our production schedule to create breathing room in between our shoots. There far too many productions that fail because the attempt to cram all of their shooting days into a short period of time (typically 25 - 40 days maximum)
In those cases the cast and crew are exhausted by the second week, and much of the original vision is lost.
 Our shooting schedule will last, on and off, from March to the end of May.
This will allow us to shoot a good deal of our exteriors first (to beat the forthcoming Texas heat) and will give us space, in between shoots, for the cast and crew to rest and for us to assemble and test our footage to better prepare for post production.
There is a good deal of practical special effects in South Texas Blues, and those days will be scheduled two separate blocks of shooting.  The effects team and production design team will be on set for most of those days, however there are other days where we will only need a minimal amount of crew.
If there's a scene where two characters are having a conversation in a country field it is not important to have a large crew of artisans on set. It can all be accomplished with a smaller crew.
We're also designing many of our shooting blocks so that particular actors can complete their parts, in a chronological sequence, and we don't waste any time.
It's this sensibility when applied to our scheduling that will save a great deal of money, time and energy.
Many of our shooting locations will be on-location in areas in and  around Austin, Texas.

Production includes but is not limited to:
general production insurance, equipment rentals, set construction, live practical make-up effects and key make-up departments,sound mixing and recording crew, catering for all cast and crew, stunts and coordination, lodging and transportation for particular cast and crew members, a general budget (payment) for all cast and crew for the duration of their (Production) working days, equipment transportation and storage for exterior location shoots, and all additional technical and logistical aspects of our production.

Post Production:
Estimated budget $15 - $20,000

 Many of our scenes will be assembled during our shoot. I applied this method during the making of Montauk Chronicles and it proved not only to be a wonderful time saver but also it allowed me to see if I needed any additional coverage during the production. These editing assemble days will take place on our scheduled "rest-days" for the crew.

I and one editing lab assistant will work through each scene to make sure we have exactly what we need to make a great movie in post production.

When we finally enter the official post production arena we will already have saved valuable amount of time and money.

Post Production will include but is not limited to:
Post visual effects, color correction and grading, sound design, editing and mixing, and general motion picture editing.


All of our sequences involving practical make-up effects and post visual effects, have already been extensively planned and storyboarded by Christopher Garetano and artist Trevor Cook.


South Texas Blues is  a movie about personal challenge and triumph in the face of great obstacles.
This project has been in my life for two decades and I could have began a crowd-source fund for it, years ago. 
I'm convinced that moviegoers want something different and exciting. They want something inspiring and to be involved in something like this project that can bring a great energy into their lives and into the world. It's the only way to make this picture. 
This story is about a man who wasn't yet a Hollywood director. He had a powerful dream and had to fight for it every step of the way. It was his faithful and talented cast and crew that helped him to ultimately create the masterpiece that it became. That is the soul of my picture.
As for the gift that I would like to share with the contributor, I sincerely want you to feel your integral part in this journey. You will receive a digital copy of the screenplay only days after your donation. Please consider yourself our official "micro-producer " and feel free to tell everyone that you are.
Consider yourself an important part of this project . I hold you in the highest regard and that's why I'm allowing you a direct window into our entire process from beginning to end. I want you to see every step of the creation process and when it's finally completed you will know, in your heart, that we all accomplished something together.


It's my humble opinion that It's important for a director to be the most experienced person on set. It's not important to be the master of all tasks but a good director must know the general language of all movie making tasks so he or she can communicate well with the cast and crew.

Movie making is in large part problem solving.

There are challenges making every motion picture, but with my current experience and our solid crew I'm more than confident that we will reach all goals. 

Making Montauk Chronicles was a series of great challenges but that's movie making and it's to be expected. I suspect it's inexperience (in all areas of movie making) that leads to most problems on a movie set.

The best way to reduce ricks and challenges on a film set, is to be prepared and hire a crew and cast that know what they're getting into.

We're prepared for the long hours and for the hard work. We're prepared to use the budget wisely and you (Our Contributors) will pay witness to the entire process through our virtual observation window. The production methods learned making my previous movie will be applied once again. We understand the difference between a movie set and a party and everyone on the set of South Texas Blues will be there to work hard and make a great movie.





We have many options and perks for those who want to contribute to this project. Even if you can't give a financial contribution for South Texas Blues, we would love it if you would spread the word to people you know who might. Enthusiasm and getting the word out is equally important.
Spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, movie sites, and anywhere else you can think of!
If you live in the Austin area (or elsewhere if you're willing to travel) contact us and let us know how you might be able to contribute. We would love to hear from you! Email us directly at southtexasblues@hotmail.com.

Thank you for your support in bringing this epic film to life.

It can all be accomplished with a smaller crew.We're also designing many of our shooting blocks so that particular actors can complete their parts, in a chronological sequence, and we don't waste any time.It's this sensibility when applied to our scheduling that will save a great deal of money, time and energy.Many of our shooting locations will be on-location in areas in and  around Austin, Texas.Production includes but is not limited to: general production insurance, equipment rentals, set construction, live practical make-up effects and key make-up departments,sound mixing and recording crew, catering for all cast and crew, stunts and coordination, lodging and transportation for particular cast and crew members, a general budget (payment) for all cast and crew for the duration of their (Production) working days, equipment transportation and storage for exterior location shoots, and all additional technical and logistical aspects of our production.Post Production:Estimated budget $15 - $20,000 Many of our scenes will be assembled during our shoot. I applied this method during the making of Montauk Chronicles and it proved not only to be a wonderful time saver but also it allowed me to see if I needed any additional coverage during the production. These editing assemble days will take place on our scheduled "rest-days" for the crew.


I and one editing lab assistant will work through each scene to make sure we have exactly what we need to make a great movie in post production.When we finally enter the official post production arena we will already have saved valuable amount of time and money.Post Production will include but is not limited to:Post visual effects, color correction and grading, sound design, editing and mixing, and general motion picture editing. 


All of our sequences involving practical make-up effects and post visual effects, have already been extensively planned and storyboarded by Christopher Garetano and artist Trevor Cook.
  



South Texas Blues is  a movie about personal challenge and triumph in the face of great obstacles.

This project has been in my life for two decades and I could have began a crowd-source fund for it, years ago. 
I'm convinced that moviegoers want something different and exciting. They want something inspiring and to be involved in something like this project that can bring a great energy into their lives and into the world. It's the only way to make this picture. 
This story is about a man who wasn't yet a Hollywood director. He had a powerful dream and had to fight for it every step of the way. It was his faithful and talented cast and crew that helped him to ultimately create the masterpiece that it became. That is the soul of my picture.
As for the gift that I would like to share with the contributor, I sincerely want you to feel your integral part in this journey. You will receive a digital copy of the screenplay only days after your donation. Please consider yourself our official "micro-producer " and feel free to tell everyone that you are.


Consider yourself an important part of this project . I hold you in the highest regard and that's why I'm allowing you a direct window into our entire process from beginning to end. I want you to see every step of the creation process and when it's finally completed you will know, in your heart, that we all accomplished something together.
   

  It's my humble opinion that It's important for a director to be the most experienced person on set. It's not important to be the master of all tasks but a good director must know the general language of all movie making tasks so he or she can communicate well with the cast and crew.
Movie making is in large part problem solving.
There are challenges making every motion picture, but with my current experience and our solid crew I'm more than confident that we will reach all goals. 
Making Montauk Chronicles was a series of great challenges but that's movie making and it's to be expected. I suspect it's inexperience (in all areas of movie making) that leads to most problems on a movie set.

The best way to reduce ricks and challenges on a film set, is to be prepared and hire a crew and cast that know what they're getting into. 
We're prepared for the long hours and for the hard work. We're prepared to use the budget wisely and you (Our Contributors) will pay witness to the entire process through our virtual observation window. The production methods learned making my previous movie will be applied once again. We understand the difference between a movie set and a party and everyone on the set of South Texas Blues will be there to work hard and make a great movie.





We have many options and perks for those who want to contribute to this project. Even if you can't give a financial contribution for South Texas Blues, we would love it if you would spread the word to people you know who might. Enthusiasm and getting the word out is equally important.
Spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, movie sites, and anywhere else you can think of!
If you live in the Austin area (or elsewhere if you're willing to travel) contact us and let us know how you might be able to contribute. We would love to hear from you! Email us directly at southtexasblues@hotmail.com.

 Thank you for your support in bringing this epic film to life.

story:
Welcome to our Wasteland!

Hi, everyone, Sam here, director of "After The Blast", at the Crows Nest studio, headquarters for all things "After The Blast", announcing the launch of a new "After The Blast" Adventure: 

"After The Blast 2: After After The Blast - The Gridiron Wasteland"!

We are going to see some spectacle, because this is the centerpiece of a trilogy of short films that will ultimately tell a complete story and reveal the secret of our Wasteland.

The post-apocalyptic wasteland of total destruction is even funnier this time. 

In the first film we caught a glimpse of life underground for some of the survivors of the mysterious Blast. Now dodge mushroom clouds and savage marauders who worship the Rule Book of Football.  See a doomsday prepper dress like a cheerleader. And watch Harry Trumbull our hero fight alongside warrior librarians to save a world already wrecked!

The Team Reunites!

Hot on the heels of the short film "Judges",  which is heading for the festivals (I was one of the producers of the Alan Chamberlain short film), and as "After The Blast" nears completion, we have begun gathering the personnel, building the sets and models, and writing the next installment of this crazy post-apocalyptic comedy-saga.

The Adventure Continues...

Our hero, Harry Trumbull, having been rescued and then sent off by the dwellers of the Presidential Emergency Disaster Shelter, now wanders the Wasteland in search of his ex-wife and millennial son. But his quest will be interrupted by the startling discovery of powerful groups of survivors who make war on one another for dominance: tribalistic football teams who look (and act) like the bad guys from "Mad Max", Wall Street raiders who now really are "dog eat dog" and "cutthroat", and machine gun-wielding librarians defending the world's last treasure house of knowledge, literature, art, beauty, and plant life. Harry just wants reconciliation with his ex, he wants to spend more time with his son, he wants to have a better relationship with his son's step dad the "I told you so" doomsday prepper, he wants some kind of normal life, but he's not going to get it - not just yet.

First, Harry has to do the whole Hero-Of-The-Wasteland/Save-The-World thing.

How You Can Make This Happen.

Now, obviously we are starting from the beginning of the process for this film. "After The Blast" had the benefit of being mostly completed before its fundraising campaign began. So we will be raising more funds this time to facilitate the complete process, and also we will once again utilize the production techniques that we have developed at Crows Nest to deliver high quality without high cost.

"After The Blast 2: After After The Blast: The Gridiron Wasteland" will make extensive use of practical miniature sets and vehicles and buildings, giving it its signature retro feel. In addition to the hard models and props and costumes already in hand, we will be adding Element 3D to our editing facilities. This software will allow us to custom-create scenes of massive armies clashing with total realism and extremely low cost when compared to a Hollywood blockbuster equivalent. 

How Really Good Can Become Great:

We have come up with a budget that guarantees completion but also allows for goals beyond the minimum we require to deliver a picture. 

We made "After The Blast" for under $5,000 so as long as we can raise that minimum we will be able to deliver at the very least the level of quality we have in the past.

Raising more funds will make it possible to incrementally add value to the project, both in terms of practical expenses (more special effects/production design) and time (more money means a less strenuous shoot schedule. That means fewer problems to solve in post-production, and that saves time and increases value. 

We don't want to put a limit on what we can raise, because we fully intend to develop the "After The Blast" property to its maximum potential and want to continually improve our product and most importantly, keep making more.

Starting with a $5,000 base budget, we will add value as we gain more funds.

For example, at a certain level of funding we will add a camera drone which will allow us to orchestrate magnificent vistas of the Wasteland and create a feeling of space and loneliness unachievable in any other way. 

This time around we will be shooting outdoors in addition to the library location we have secured. The desert environs outside of L.A. will provide nature's contribution to our production value.

So, this is the framework we are thinking of for a scaled budget: 

$5,000- Basic Budget - low shoot days, equipment, props amortized, salaries deferred
$8,000 - Budget Plus - We will add the camera drone and more shoot days/locations.
$15,000 - "Full" Budget - This fulfills the budget breakdown (cost estimations) as written.
$15,000 and above - We will add line items to the budget incrementally "as needed" to increase the film's value, for example:
  • More shoot days, more locations
  • Editor - I cut the 1st "After The Blast" but will gladly relinquish the editor's chair.
  • Stage Rental
  • Bigger crew (bigger crew means less multitasking, more efficient production)
  • Better Craft Services and Meals
  • "Name" Guest Star Actor
  • "Hit" song
  • "Name" composer to score the film
  • Larger epic scenes using many actor "extras" in conjunction with computer generated images
  • More money for promotion, promotional items, promotional events, P.R., Social Media Optimization
  • Upgraded Website
  • More money for festival entry
  • More money for distribution to online platforms for sales.
All of these goals are clearly aimed at publicizing our efforts and monetizing the "After The Blast" brand and maintaining it as a going concern.

The Perks.

Our perks are immersive and fun. Part of the joy of creating a "universe" like this is being able to extend the experience beyond the movie. By contributing, you are joining us in creating and perpetuating this.

The Impact.

The first "After The Blast" short grew out of a workshop that I organized, and we tried to emulate a number of my favorite directors' styles, like Paul Greengrass, Francis Coppola, Stanley Kubrick, Robert Altman, Tony Scott, the writing style of Bill Forsythe. I felt we were successful in that, and so we will continue that tradition into the second film. George Miller, that's a no-brainer. This movie has a heavy element of "Mad Max" - the original story was predominantly parody of the original Mad Max movies. What timing. David Lean, Werner Herzog - oh yes, we will be going out of doors to shoot this one, to exotic deserts like the Owens Valley or Mojave. Oh, and then there is football, so get out your "Rollerball", your "Varsity Blues" - dare I say there will be shades of Steve Sabol here? Hmmm…. And there is a core section involving the siege of a public library that may remind you of John Carpenter's "Assault on Precinct 13", which by the way has some very funny moments. More proof you can make something funny in the middle of catastrophe.

And "After The Blast 2: After After The Blast: The Gridiron Wasteland" is a cliffhanger, leading straight into the third chapter and the revelation of the secret of our Wasteland!

You can be a part of this. You can in fact be the force that makes this adventure not only possible, but wildly successful.  We are paving the way for more and bigger adventures and new films. 

Risks & Challenges

Though grand in scale and location, the core scenes will center around set pieces and most importantly, the characters. Reference "Assault on Precinct 13" (the 1976 John Carpenter film, not, I repeat, not the remake) and you can see how a little crafty filmmaking on a low budget can stretch "four people in a room talking" into "four people in a room under siege by a nameless horde".

And remember, this is a short film, which lightens the load somewhat when it comes to the number of rabbits we are going to be pulling out of our hats when it comes to our visual trickery.  And, we are at a kind of magical moment in time, where easily accessible technology makes great leaps possible by providing the small-scale filmmaker with the tools of a master.

Clearly, this is a particular style of cinema. But for us, "low budget" does not mean low quality. It means I am writing the script with built-in "Crows Nest Customization", carefully crafting it to tell a grand story without having to hurdle obstacles of money and time by knowing inside and out our capabilities as a filmmaking group. It means actor/producer Mark Taormino (who is also one of the stars of "After The Blast") will provide his complete and wholly owned camera equipment package free of charge. It means Crows Nest Vertical Pictures has its own prop and costume collection, with an emphasis on sci-fi/military. It means there are vastly talented people willing to take a chance on the success of a project they can directly affect for the better.  And it means we live and produce in Los Angeles, the greatest source of talented, trained, educated, dedicated and experienced film artists, technicians and actors in the history of the world.

Most importantly, we shoot well-crafted scripts that tell compelling stories that despite the over-the-top subject and style are always about the landscape of the human soul, the human experience, where we've been and where we're going. The short film I co-produced with Mark Taormino, director Alan Chamberlain's  "Judges", is a great example of that dramatic exploration. It also shows clearly our level of capability in terms of quality and visual style. This project was done with the same ways and means as "After The Blast", but without the benefit of a fundraising campaign. I think the results are spectacular.

And we are blessed to have such great talent eager to help us fulfill our visions and achieve our overarching mission: to present movie-watching experiences as fun and fulfilling as any other.

So the question is not so much "Can we do it?" because we've done it, going on twice now. The question is, "How far can we take this?"

And the answer is in your hands.

You have the power to make it all happen, and to be along for the ride. You can be the wind in our sails as we continue to develop "After The Blast" as a going concern.

We will be here, keeping you updated on all things "After After The Blast" and taking you to the Wasteland - and beyond….

Thank you!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know some of you may want to support this project but just can't contribute. If you have a special skill, a special prop or costume, or even know of a location or other asset that would enhance our story, please feel free to contact us here. (I know for a fact we're going to be on the hunt for some football equipment.)

Also, making some noise about our campaign can be equally helpful. (Indiegogo has great share tools that make it easy to get the word out.) Folks might find what we are doing as filmmakers and how we are approaching the process to be an interesting story to follow. As the campaign progresses, we hope to provide entertaining updates so it will be fun to check back in.

And more than anything, to quote the great (if fictional) Steve Zissou:

"This is an adventure."

story:
The Biltmore Academy

The Biltmore Academy is about a little boy who doesn’t understand why he can’t wear his favorite dress to school. His private school, The Biltmore Academy, has a rule that all boys need to wear slacks. This rule makes no sense to Nicholas, a smart and curious 6-year-old who would much rather prefer to wear a nice dress every day. 

His mother, Nadine, agrees with his choice, and will support him no matter what. His other mother, Susan, comes from a different perspective. She’s the one who has to get him dressed in the morning, and has to manage the temper tantrums when Nicholas is forced to wear boy’s clothing. She’s the one who has to endure the withering stares of other mothers who don’t approve of Nicholas’s unconventional preferences. Susan has to enforce a rule that she doesn’t believe in – that boys have to be one way and girls another – so that Nicholas can get the benefits of an elite education. But is education worth it if Nicholas is miserable every day? Are these rules worth following if they threaten Susan and Nadine’s marriage?

Nicholas doesn’t have any political agenda – he’s just a little boy who likes what he likes. It’s his mothers, a lawyer and an actress, who have to reconcile their beliefs with the realities of this world. Sometimes we have to pretend to be something that we’re not in order to succeed. But is this a lesson a 6 year old needs to learn? At what age is personal compromise necessary? How old are we allowed to get before we’re no longer allowed to be ourselves? 

Based on the screenwriter’s play, The Biltmore Academy is a short film about visibility, identity, and acceptance. It’s about a pair of progressive parents who struggle to find the right tools and vocabulary to help their son through an unusually difficult early childhood. It’s about a little boy who doesn’t even know that he’s different. He just knows what kind of clothes he likes to wear.

What We Need

In order to make sure this film reaches a wide audience we need to use sound and video recording equipment of a professional caliber. We will be shooting on an F7, a new Sony 35mm affordable yet very high quality camera that cuts down on color editing costs due to its dynamic range and low contrast image. We will also be using boom and body (lavaliere microphones) to create a professionally clear sound for the film. Not only are lavaliere body microphones important for isolating voices to create a high quality of sound, they are an absolute necessity when working with child actors to be sure their voices can be heard clearly. Though we have a script, we will be improvising a portion of this film. So it is especially important to make sure the sound support for our main character Nicholas, age 6, is in place to capture what he is saying in those improvised moments or the text, which will be in his own words, may be lost. Many films that make it into major film festivals (Sundance, Tribeca Film Festival, Cannes, OutFest), which reach large audiences, use similar equipment.

In addition to equipment all meals, set dressings, props, editing, insurance, wardrobe, labor, and location/travel expenses will be drawn from our $3K budget. All actors, artists, and creatives involved in this project will be working for meals, copy, and credit only on this project. We are operating under a SAG Short Film Agreement. 

Our total budget for this film, including equipment donated by Columbia University is projected to be $3K.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in a financial position to help us out with The Biltmore Academy there are other ways to help. Please share this campaign with friends, family, and anyone who might be interested in our story. 

Click to like our Facebook page, follow us on Twitter, & show us some social media love! 

Cast and Creative Team

Jody Christopherson (Susan/Producer) As a generative artist Jody creates and performs interactive events within the context of theater, film/new media and music. Her transmedia event The Skype Show or See You in August has recently been presented by The New York International Fringe Festival (2013), Filmgate Miami, The Brick Theater and StoryCode (2014). Other works include the performance/ photography exibit Necessary Exposure: The Female Playwright Project (currently on display at Dixon Place through Jan 26th), the international theatrical band Greencard Wedding(DROM, Fat Baby, Parkside Lounge, Lower East Side Music Festival, INTAR Theater and more),Eschaton Cabaret (Dixon Place, Bowery Poetry Club), DIVE (Philadelphia Shakespeare Classical Cabaret)Like This (Winner of The Exquisite Corpse Film Festival NYC).

Sola Fasehun (Lead Producer) Sola is a Nigerian American producer/writer/SAG eligible actress based in New York. She graduated undergrad w/ college & university honors from Carnegie Mellon University w/ a BHA degree. After CMU, Sola moved to LA and interned with Academy Award winning producer Michael Phillips (Taxi Driver, The Sting) in Beverly Hills. Sola also worked on the annual Jerry Lewis Telethon for two years and began an independent film company: Fasehun Films. In NY, Sola was an associate producer on the first Broadway revival of Godspell (starring Orange is the New Black’s Uzo Aduba), founded a film program at a middle school in Manhattan, traveled to Africa to produce a feature documentary, was an entertainment writer for the LA based magazine Campus Circle, and as an ASCAP songwriter for Danceaholic Records/Universal Music Group, Sola produced music videos for artists on the label and wrote songs featured on I-Tunes.

Recently a film Sola produced (Foreign Sounds) was accepted into the 2015 Cannes Film Festival Short Film Corner. Sola was one of the producers of the film Broken Badge which was executive produced by Academy Award nominated Michael Hausman (Gangs of New York, Brokeback Mountain). One of Sola’s recent film producing projects (The Women of Dev Saab) was awarded the 2015 Panavision/Columbia University Production Grant. Sola was also accepted into the 2015 P.G.A. East Student Program. Currently Sola is a sales and distribution consultant at Submarine Entertainment/Submarine Deluxe (Winter’s Bone, Citizenfour). She is set to graduate from Columbia University’s Graduate Film Program in the fall of 2015.

Ellie Foumbi (Director) is a screenwriting/director in the MFA program at Columbia University. She’s written and directed two short films. The latest, Avalanche, is in the process of being submitted to festivals. It's an 11-mintue psychological horror about a young wife who descends into downward spiral when she begins to suspect that her husband is unfaithful. For this film, she was awarded a Next-Wave grant from New York Women in Film and Television. She’s currently co-producing other films, including Search Party, a Columbia University non-thesis film which won the 2015 HBO production grant. 

Jeffrey James Keyes (Writer/Producer) was recently commissioned by Lexus to story produce on the ten-part travel series Out in GayCities and worked as the Associate Producer on the new Sundance series, Revealing, featuring Joe Zee from Elle Magazine and two episodes of MTV's True Life. His short film, 181 is currently in post-production and his new web series, 5 to 9 is also filming this summer. Recent theater credits include: The End of Days (SoHo Playhouse/New York International Fringe Festival), Imaginary Friends (Samuel French Festival, Chicago’s Prologue Theatre), I'm From Driftwood (Project Y/Access Theater), Immortal: The Gilgamesh Variations (Bushwick Starr), Dance Dance Arden (3LD), Cell Beget Cell (Old Vic Theater, London), Room 407 (59E59), Josh Groban Fanclub (Ensemble Studio Theatre), Into the Shallow End (Ensemble Studio Theatre), Moonshine on the Rocks (78th Street Theater Project), and Williamsburg (Manhattan Rep). Jeffrey James has additionally has written for Metrosource, Instinct, Out, The Advocate, and Passport Magazines and his work is featured in Italy From A Backpack and Stage This. BA: Fordham University College at the Lincoln Center, MFA Columbia University School of the Arts. 

Michael Niederman (Director) is an accomplished screenwriter. His script for the film Billion Star Hotel is was shot in Cambodia and received multiple international releases.His script for the short film Proof of Birth won the Broadcast Educational Association Best Screenplay Award, and Faculty Selects at the Columbia University Film Festival.His feature length screenplay, Saint Carlos of Gowanus also won Faculty Selects at Columbia University, was featured at the National Association of Independent Latino Producers Writer’s Lab, and was a finalist for the Sundance Film Festival Writer’s Lab.

Michael is the Director for New Works at Ignited States, a member of the National Association of Latino Independent Producers (NALIP), and is a founding member and producer of the Crosstown Playwrights.  He is a veteran of various writers workshops at theaters all over New York, including Pataphysics at The Flea, ESPA at Primary Stages, and The New York Neo Futurists, and the Actor’s Studio Writers/Directors Lab. is the author of the plays Freshman Fifteen (NYC Actors Studio), The Riverside Symphony (Planet Connections Theater Festivity), The Kuptferberg Family Tragedy (New York Stage and Film), To Barcelona! (Ignited States), Alvin Saves The Day, Good Men, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays (Risley Theater), Running Across Amsterdam (American Theater for the Actors), Chelsea, Alaska (New Ohio Theater) and The Eschaton Caberet (Bowery Poetry Club.

Carolyn Michelle Smith (Nadie/Producer) Recent credits include: Broadway's "Romeo and Juliet" directed by David Leveaux. Off-Broadway: "Hit The Wall" by Ike Holter (Barrow Street Theatre), "Serial. Black. Face" Workshop (Signature Theatre), "Soldier X". (Ma-Yi Theatre Company) Regional: "WHADDABLOODCLOT!!!" by Katori Hall (Williamstown Theatre Festival), "Rich Girl" by Victoria Stewart, (Old Globe Theatre), Actors Theatre of Louisville, Seattle Shakespeare Company, and Princeton Rep. TV: "Codes of Conduct" directed by Steve McQueen (HBO), and "House of Cards" recurring role of "Willa". (Netflix) Training: Fordham University at Lincoln Center (B.A), BADA-Midsummer at Oxford, and Juilliard.
story_txt:
The Biltmore Academy

The Biltmore Academy is about a little boy who doesn’t understand why he can’t wear his favorite dress to school. His private school, The Biltmore Academy, has a rule that all boys need to wear slacks. This rule makes no sense to Nicholas, a smart and curious 6-year-old who would much rather prefer to wear a nice dress every day. His mother, Nadine, agrees with his choice, and will support him no matter what. His other mother, Susan, comes from a different perspective. She’s the one who has to get him dressed in the morning, and has to manage the temper tantrums when Nicholas is forced to wear boy’s clothing. She’s the one who has to endure the withering stares of other mothers who don’t approve of Nicholas’s unconventional preferences. Susan has to enforce a rule that she doesn’t believe in – that boys have to be one way and girls another – so that Nicholas can get the benefits of an elite education. But is education worth it if Nicholas is miserable every day? Are these rules worth following if they threaten Susan and Nadine’s marriage?Nicholas doesn’t have any political agenda – he’s just a little boy who likes what he likes. It’s his mothers, a lawyer and an actress, who have to reconcile their beliefs with the realities of this world. Sometimes we have to pretend to be something that we’re not in order to succeed. But is this a lesson a 6 year old needs to learn? At what age is personal compromise necessary? How old are we allowed to get before we’re no longer allowed to be ourselves? Based on the screenwriter’s play, The Biltmore Academy is a short film about visibility, identity, and acceptance. It’s about a pair of progressive parents who struggle to find the right tools and vocabulary to help their son through an unusually difficult early childhood. It’s about a little boy who doesn’t even know that he’s different. He just knows what kind of clothes he likes to wear.
   What We Need 
In order to make sure this film reaches a wide audience we need to use sound and video recording equipment of a professional caliber. We will be shooting on an F7, a new Sony 35mm affordable yet very high quality camera that cuts down on color editing costs due to its dynamic range and low contrast image. We will also be using boom and body (lavaliere microphones) to create a professionally clear sound for the film. Not only are lavaliere body microphones important for isolating voices to create a high quality of sound, they are an absolute necessity when working with child actors to be sure their voices can be heard clearly. Though we have a script, we will be improvising a portion of this film. So it is especially important to make sure the sound support for our main character Nicholas, age 6, is in place to capture what he is saying in those improvised moments or the text, which will be in his own words, may be lost. Many films that make it into major film festivals (Sundance, Tribeca Film Festival, Cannes, OutFest), which reach large audiences, use similar equipment.
In addition to equipment all meals, set dressings, props, editing, insurance, wardrobe, labor, and location/travel expenses will be drawn from our $3K budget. All actors, artists, and creatives involved in this project will be working for meals, copy, and credit only on this project. We are operating under a SAG Short Film Agreement. 

Our total budget for this film, including equipment donated by Columbia University is projected to be $3K.

    Other Ways You Can Help If you're not in a financial position to help us out with The Biltmore Academy there are other ways to help. Please share this campaign with friends, family, and anyone who might be interested in our story. 
Click to like our Facebook page, follow us on Twitter, & show us some social media love! 

Cast and Creative Team


Jody Christopherson (Susan/Producer) As a generative artist Jody creates and performs interactive events within the context of theater, film/new media and music. Her transmedia event The Skype Show or See You in August has recently been presented by The New York International Fringe Festival (2013), Filmgate Miami, The Brick Theater and StoryCode (2014). Other works include the performance/ photography exibit Necessary Exposure: The Female Playwright Project (currently on display at Dixon Place through Jan 26th), the international theatrical band Greencard Wedding(DROM, Fat Baby, Parkside Lounge, Lower East Side Music Festival, INTAR Theater and more),Eschaton Cabaret (Dixon Place, Bowery Poetry Club), DIVE (Philadelphia Shakespeare Classical Cabaret)Like This (Winner of The Exquisite Corpse Film Festival NYC).

She graduated undergrad w/ college & university honors from Carnegie Mellon University w/ a BHA degree. One of Sola’s recent film producing projects (The Women of Dev Saab) was awarded the 2015 Panavision/Columbia University Production Grant. Sola was also accepted into the 2015 P.G.A. East Student Program. Currently Sola is a sales and distribution consultant at Submarine Entertainment/Submarine Deluxe (Winter’s Bone, Citizenfour). story:
THANK YOU TO ALL WHO CONTRIBUTED  TO THIS  MIGHTY CAMPAIGN! Thousands saw the film on opening weekend and we were #2 at the theaters in the 25 cities and the #1 Independent Film in the U.S.

Hollywood rejected the film for being 'too God-Centered'. One studio executive said, "You mention God in almost every scene."

We're taking 'David and Goliath' and our latest film, 'Epic Journey' out to the world this year. As a thank you, we're giving you 'DAVID AND GOLIATH' (DVD + Blu-Ray) as a special gift with your donation.

Not Available on Amazon, Walmart, Best Buy or anywhere until October - YOU GET IT NOW!

Watch the Epic Trailer:


See the 30-Second TV ad on CNN, Fox News, Lifetime, ESPN, TBN, Discovery, History, etc:

 

Read the Latest Articles:

'David and Goliath' movie to feature real life giant, 7'8" Jerry Sokoloski

Why the New Movie ‘David and Goliath’ will Outshine ‘Noah’ and ‘Exodus’

‘David and Goliath’ is Next in Line of Religious Epics


See the Live Reaction:


Please Support Our New Film 'EPIC JOURNEY' - 36 Countries. 25 Stories. 1 Amazing God. CLICK HERE TO SEE THE TRAILER:

story:
Catmageddon is upon us!  Cats will soon take over the world if we don't step up and pay attention.  Cat cafes are popping up all over the place and this is just the beginning!  Catmageddon is a weekly Youtube series that pulls the best cat related clips and stories from the week and shows us just how close we are to a Catocracy.  Hosted by the witty, sharp tongued, but incredibly adorable Ambassador to the Great Cat Empire Catmageddon willl make you laugh, cry, and re-up on shotgun shells and catnip.  

We need money to pay our team of crack investigative reporters and video production specialists so they can eat and pay their internet bills while they save the world.  These unsung heroes will eventually become sung heroes with your support.  So please donate, donate , donate!  Unless of course however you are totally cool being ruled by cats.  Even if you are cool with a world full of scratching posts and FroliCat machines donating will still contribute to an awesome cat show!

story:
The accumulated amount goes to the nonprofit Organisation Govinda e.V. to help people in Nepal.

____________________________________________________________________

Mustafa Oguzhan: Leitung Projekt „ LOVE UNITES “ ARTIST


I am a 34 year old artist living in Graz, Austria. My parents and I moved from Turkey to Austria in 1989. There were some difficulties at the beginning, but after overcoming them, I studied to be an electrician and thereafterI started working as an instructor at the AMS. Now, in participation with LOVE Wins, I have decided to travel around the world to spread our message. Solidarity, love, and the urge to help others motivates me. I not only want my children to have a better future, I want a better future for everyone.


Projekt: 39.000 miles for Charity "LOVE UNITES" hosted by                                                   LOVE Wins

Start: Slovenian border by foot

Current location: Istanbul 

Next stop: Azerbaijan by horse 


In order to achieve this we need your help. You can help those in need with a 'Like', with a 'Share', with material donations such as shoes, t-shirts etc, or by donating money.
LOVE Unite is a project which needs your donation so that Mustafa Oguzhan can not only help people but also bring people and cultures closer together through pictures and video clips.
Mustafa will identify the most pressing problems children are facing in each of the countries he is visiting and trying to make the right contacts with local organisations and individuals - who will then partner with Love Wins and support our charity projects on site.

The goal of this project is to travel once around the world.

You can follow his journey on our homepage: LOVE Wins

Goals: 
  • To improve goal-oriented help projects on location 
  • To find qualified volunteers Pictures, Videos and stories for Love Wins 
  • To implement the developed projects 
  • To sensitise the conditions by bringing them to people's attention and reporting on them 
  •  To distribute the message of equality and love around the world

Mustafa @ Work near Samsun

Love wins: What drives you Mr Mustafa? 
Mustafa: I am driven by the will to stir things up, to change things. I believe the biggest change takes places in each of our heads. 
Love wins: How did you feel about giving up your job in Austria in order to work with Love Wins? 
Mustafa: I'm full of pride and honour because I finally feel like I am doing something worthwhile. 
Love wins: What are your goals in regards to this trip? 
Mustafa: To gain new impressions in order to validate my decision. To bring love to the world. But above all, my main objective is to build a relationship with the locals and those affected, so that one can provide a sustainable collaboration.


_____________________________________________________________________________

LOVE Wins 

The organisation Love wins helps upcoming artists plan and implement charitable street art projects. The main objective of these projects is to raise awareness and provide help for children with needs, such as orphans, children on the street and many others. 

 In order to do that, specific projects, such as BAMBSY, are chosen and from their planning to their realisation they are professionally accompanied by the creative and media sector. Our network of sponsors and companies enables us to implement non-profit art projects in cities and therefore support the particular charitable project.

_____________________________________________________________________________

The collected money will be donated to the nonprofit Organisation Govinda e.V. to help people in Nepal.


Thank You!

story:
Hello there! I'm Patrick aged 24 yrs old. I live in Mauritius and actually work as a freelance model and graphic designer. I'm extremely passionate about design, filmmaking, software, etc. I am an autodidact and i'm proud of what i've achieved since the past years. I can now work on After effects, photoshop, illustrator, zbrush, blender etc.. and master them sufficiently to help me realise one of my childhood dream... producing my own superhero movie!

However, filmmaking is not much developed in Mauritius. Well, despite all odds, I still have the ambition of making my own film about a guy who has inspired me since my childhood and continues to do so nowadays... his name is Clark Kent. We call him Superman.. I've always been that kind of person who wants to help people out of their trouble. I think that in the world we are living now, we need more and more people who devote their time and efforts in helping each other. Just imagine a world like that..full of compassion, love and consideration for each other. In fact, this is one of the reasons why i want to do that film. I want people to be inspired by this Superhero in their daily life. I not only want to promote filmmaking in Mauritius, but also want to get people to adopt a new way of life, to show to the youth that they can achieve what they want, if they believe in it and in themselves. Look at me for instance, i have got the passion, the ambition, the dream, the actors, the support from family and friends...but unfortunately no funds. And that is why i'm turning to you today. I will never let go.

For sure, the money will go into the purchase of the following equipment: lights, microphone, lenses, Audio Gear, Camera Gear like Cameras, Lenses, Rigs (dollies, sliders), Better Locations , Green Screen, Studio Rentals, Post Production Plugins & Software (Better VFX) etc.. I have started to save and invest in the following: 1 light, some gears, and lens filters. 

This is a non-profit passion project! all the money raised will be invested in making my childhood dream turn into a reality... heartfelt thanks to you in contributing and above all believing in such a special project...for me, for young people, for us.

P.S : Please also see below link to a newspaper release about my project. ( it's in French )

Online Newspaper link : http://www.defimedia.info/defi-quotidien/dq-mag...

Facebook page : https://www.facebook.com/pages/Man-of-Steel-Fan...?
